title: LA R users group: LA East R Users: Creating custom vector classes with vctrs & Python for R Users
description:
Talk 1:
Speaker: Jesse Sadler (@vivalosburros), Loyola Marymount University, Department of History
website: jessesadler.com
Title: vctrs: Creating custom vector classes with the vctrs package

Abstract:
The base R types of vectors enable the representation of an amazingly wide array of data types. There is so much you can do with R. However, there may be times when your data does not fit into one of the base types and/or you want to add metadata to vectors. vctrs is a developer-focused package that provides a clear path for creating your own S3-vector class, while ensuring that the class integrates into user expectations for how vectors work in R. This talk will discuss the why and how of using vctrs through the example of debkeepr, a package for integrating historical non-decimal currencies such as pounds, shillings, and pence into R.

Talk 2:
Speaker: Sylvia Tran (www.linkedin.com/in/sylvia-s-tran/)
Title: Python for R Users

Abstract:
The switch from Python to R or R to Python doesn’t always feel natural. In this talk, Sylvia will help draw some parallels and leave you with a high-level cheat sheet for how to do the following using pandas and scikit, learn without having to get into the low-level weeds of Python object types.
a) light data cleaning / standardizing features
b) train-test-split
c) pipe your data into a model
d) evaluate model performance

Code of Conduct: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

Timeline:
6:30: Socializing
7:00-8:00: Talks
8:00: Socializing

Address:
Room 115/116
USC
2001 N. Soto St.
Los Angeles, CA 90032

Invite yourself to our Slack group: http://bit.ly/laerug
Ask us any questions by email: [masked]
Find our previous talks on GitHub: https://github.com/laeRusers/presentations
Follow us on Twitter: @laeRusers
Check out more events: https://laocr.org/

title: Oxford R User Group: September OxfordRUG meeting
description:
Agenda:

6:00 pm: Jakob Theorell -- Building and publishing R packages: lessons learnt while turning code snippets into DepecheR

7:00 pm: Pizza!

###

Dr Jakob Theorell (https://twitter.com/JakobTheorell)

Title: Building and publishing R packages: lessons learnt while turning code snippets into DepecheR

Description: In this session, we will discuss the reasons behind, and a way to, creating your own R package, through the eyes of a medic-and-devout-cytometrist-turned-BioConductor maintainer. We will also discuss parallelizing code, the BioConductor review process, and get into some detail about the DepecheR package (https://bioconductor.org/packages/release/bioc/html/DepecheR.html), which aims at identifying significant biological traits in noisy and complex data generated with flow/mass cytometry or scRNAseq.

###

Oxford RUG is thrilled to be sponsored by Mango Solutions. Thanks to their generosity, there will be pizza from Franco Manca after the meeting. When RSVPing, please let us know whether you will be staying for pizza (so we get a sense how much pizza to order).

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Convolutional Neural Networks and Using C++ in R with RCpp
description:
# Introduction

Ash will cover the architecture of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). The Convolution and Pooling operations will be covered. Tools for building a CNN are R and TensorFlow. The implementation of CNN in R will be demonstrated.

Luke will talk about using C++ in R. Are is a beautiful language but some operations can be slow. The RCpp package makes this an easy talk and can drastically improve the performance of your code.

Come early, network, enjoy the food and talks.

# Schedule
6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 7:30 Convolutional Neural Networks
7:30 - 8:00 Speeding up R with Rcpp
8:00 - Raffle
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

# Talk 1

## Title: Convolutional Neural Networks
## Speaker: Ash Pahwa
## Abstract
A convolutional neural network (CNN) is a class of deep neural networks used primarily for analyzing visual imagery. CNNs are used for object recognition in an image. Autonomous cars use CNN technology to navigate smoothly on the roads. There are many biomedical applications where CNN is used for image analysis.

The motivation for CNN originated from the Hubel & Wiesel (Noble prize winners 1981) study of the human visual system. This research leads to the idea that if we apply the convolution operations to the image and then feed them to neural networks, the accuracy of object identification increases. This idea started the revolution of CNN.

This talk will cover the architecture of CNN. The Convolution and Pooling operations will be covered. Tools for building a CNN are R and TensorFlow. The implementation of CNN in R will be demonstrated.

# Talk 2

## Title: Speeding up R with Rcpp
## Speaker: Luke Klein
## Abstract
R is a beautiful and flexible language, and it is improving all the time. However, some processes (e.g. repeated function calls) can add a lot of computational overhead. Rcpp is a package for extending R with C++ functions which is utilized by over 1000 packages on CRAN. Many R data types and objects can be mapped back and forth to C++ equivalents which facilitates both writing new code for people just learning C++, as well as easier integration of third-party libraries. In this talk, I'll demonstrate how easy it is to get started with Rcpp and what kind of performance boosts one can achieve. If you're taking aim at levelling-up your function writing skills then Rcpp is the place to start.

# Sponsor

Kforce is an international staffing firm specialized in the IT and Finance and Accounting space. We work with 70% of fortune 100s as well mid to smaller businesses in local markets. We build relationships and are genuinely interested in what you do. If you are looking for a new opportunity or need assistance in finding top talent we can align you to that goal.

Download our Job Board app and receive referral fees on average $500-$1000 https://kfrc.co/download

Contact: John Nacy – Managing Director of Technology at Kforce, [masked]

title: PhillyR: Visual Analytics: From Data to Insights (BC Kwon)
description:
University of Pennsylvania Penn Data Science Group (PDSG) invites PhillyR members to a data visualization seminar featuring Professor BC Kwon, a Data Visualization Research Scientist at IBM T.J. Watson Research Center. Prof. BC Kwon will give a talk on his research into effective data visualization — how do you make visualization which give clear insights into your data? He will give special mention to “trickier” forms of data, such as time series data.

Agenda:

5 PM - Networking
~ 5:15 PM - seminar start
~ 6:15 PM - Q&A, networking

The lecture will take place in Towne Hall Room 337.

Towne Hall is connected to several other engineering buildings and can be tricky to navigate. The easiest entrance is through Levine Hall, which adjoins Towne:
https://www.facilities.upenn.edu/maps/locations/levine-hall-melvin-and-claire-weiss-tech-house
Go to the *4th* floor of Levine Hall via the elevator and follow the signs to the 3rd floor of Towne (4th floor Levine = 3rd floor Towne).
I've hung signs on the 3rd floor of Towne to give directions to the room.

Date and time are confirmed. Food and drinks are served. Please RSVP on this meetup page so we can estimate attendee counts.

Note: PDSG is generously opening the seminar to non-Penn students free of charge. However, donations are appreciated to cover costs for non-Penn students.

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: TalkR
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
Attendee lead meeting in a casual setting.

There is no set agenda. We just work on things as they come up.
A new R UseR? We can help show you the ropes.
Confident in your base skills but got a tricky bug? We can help you squish it.
Experienced lone wolf? Let's talk deployment strategies and workflows, and share your experience with the group.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Cork (Ireland) R-Users Group: 2-day R workshop for beginners
description:
We are delighted to offer a 2-day introduction to the statistical language R. No previous experience of R is expected. This course is free to attend and will take place in UCC.

Over the two days we will cover data handling, data visualisation, reproducible research, project-oriented workflows, and statistics with a focus on the R language and RStudio.
The teachers are Dr Enrico Pirotta (https://labs.wsu.edu/leslie-new/people/), Dr Adam Kane (https://people.ucd.ie/adam.kane) and Dr Brendan Palmer (https://www.ucc.ie/en/publichealth/people/estaff/drbrendanpalmer/).

Please email [masked] with your expression of interest as spaces on the course will be limited to ~30 people. We look forward to hearing from you.

title: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group: Teaching neuroscience students R and the tidyverse, and opendatatoronto!
group: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group
description:
Please join us for another meetup! We have Shreejoy Tripathy and Sharla Gelfand discussing, of course, R.

-- Talk Abstracts --

Shreejoy Tripathy: Come for the machine learning, stay for the data science

As a basic neuroscience researcher and UofT professor who uses machine learning, I often receive requests by students to gain experience in machine learning and AI. In this talk, I'll share some of my experiences teaching students the basics of data science using R and the Tidyverse in the context of neuroscience research projects. I'll discuss how they're often pleased (and disappointed) that machine learning is often just a one line call to an external toolbox and how most of the work in data science is actually data cleaning, quality control, and plotting.

Sharla Gelfand: opendatatoronto R package

opendatatoronto is an R package designed to access data directly from the City of Toronto Open Data Portal in R. I'll talk a bit about the portal, open data, and explore some of the functionality and data available.

Doors will open at 6:00pm, with talks kicking off at 6:30. We'll be out by 8:00. Hope to see you there!

Thank you to The Jonah Group for having us again!

Please note that the event space is up several flights of stairs and that regrettably, it is not an accessible space. There are two gendered washrooms.

By attending, you agree to abide by our code of conduct. We use (and enforce) the R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: Adelaide R Users Group: R Users Adelaide - Spring Edition
description:
For our Spring meet-up, we have four guest speakers from academia, industry and government each giving a short talk on how they use R.

Everyone is welcome! Regardless of your experience with R, if you use R or would be interested in using R then you are welcome.

The short talks will be:

Rachel Searston
Using exciting new approaches to visualizing human data with ggplot2 for more meaningful and reproducible visualizations of data in psychology research.

Rory Tarnow-Mordi
Sometimes our datasets are just too darn big. In this talk we'll look at using SparkR to spread our data and data transformations over a cluster of machines.

Kristen Osborne
Putting R in the internet tubes; An introduction to blogdown! Blogdown is an R package that lets you create websites from R Markdown documents, making it easy to put your R code and outputs online. It creates a static website you can host on any server with minimal effort. In this talk we'll cover what blogdown is and why you might want to use it, look at some easy ways to get started, and share resources to take you further.

Jonathan Carroll
Got lots of loops or repetitive calculating to do? In this talk I'll walk through the basics of synchronous vs asynchronous processing and demonstrate some ways to perform calculations in parallel (or offsite) based on the {future} package.

This R meet-up is governed by the R Community Code of Conduct: https://wiki.r-consortium.org/view/R_Consortium_and_the_R_Community_Code_of_Conduct

Be prepared to recall some slides of the most inspiring talks of the useR! 2019 conference (http://www.user2019.fr) from Toulouse, see featured photos taken at the networking events, hear some backstage stories of the R gurus shared with us in person after the conference hours but not on Twitter yet. Most talks will be in English. Speakers: Alex Trickey, András Bérczi, Ildikó Czeller, Csenge Tarnói and Gergely Daróczi.

title: Berlin R Users Group: #39 WhyR pre-meeting: Segmentation in Surveys using NMF (talk+workshop)
description:
This pre-meeting promotes Why R? 2019 Conference whyr.pl/2019 (regular registration ends August 31st!)

Working with high dimensional data? Often facing the need to group observations? This presentation is for you.

Segmentation should be balanced and distinctive, the discovered over- and under-indexed features within segments should create a meaningful story, and, ideally, the amount of differentiative factors that drives segmentation should be small.

The last requirement often becomes a bottleneck in a survey where respondents are asked an enormous amount of questions. One solution is the non-negative matrix factorization that, in one attempt, segments respondents and their features! The concept of the NMF decomposition and applications in R will be presented with the explanation of diagnostic plots.

The 30-minute presentation will be followed by a 60-minute workshop, so bring your laptops!

As usual, short contributions and announcements from the audience are always welcome. We want to be a diverse and inclusive group, please come, bring your friends. We're hoping for a nice crowd enjoying interesting talks and chats.

Our generous host Europace AG will prepare drinks and snacks for us!

See you there!

About the Speaker:

Marcin Kosiński has a master degree in Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis specialty. Challenges seeker and devoted R language enthusiast. In the past, keen on the field of large-scale online learning and various approaches to personalized news article recommendation.

Community events host: organizer of Why R? conferences whyr.pl. Interested in R packages development and survival analysis models.

Currently explores and improves methods for quantitative marketing analyses and global surveys at Gradient Metrics.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): Use Cases of R at Ahold Delhaize & Using Reticulate in your Workflow (2 talks!)
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
September Boston UseR Group Event
We will have two presentations at this event:

+ Use Cases of R at Ahold Delhaize
+ Using Reticulate in your Workflow (how to use both Python and R together)

Abstract #1:
In this presentation, we’ll discuss how the US data science team at Ahold Delhaize uses R. We’ll cover our development and deployment processes. Then we’ll show a coding example of one of our favorite libraries, BSTS (Bayesian structural time series). We rely on this package for forecasting and temporal causal inference modeling.

Speaker:
Matt Phair is Ahold Delhaize’s US Manager of Data Science. This team develops algorithms to support the organization’s subsidiary companies with all things personalization and customer-facing. Whether recommendation engines, forecasting algorithms, or constrained optimization tools this team uses data science to improve customer experiences and optimize operations.

Abstract #2:
With the publication of the reticulate package, R users can now integrate Python into their workflow and Python users can take advantage of R Markdown and other R libraries. In this talk, we’ll explore some of the differences in presentation between Python code in Jupyter Notebook and R Markdown as we look at some time series data. Additionally, we’ll look at ways to work with combined code, using Python to import and handle data and then make some plots in ggplot.

Speaker:
Bryan Butler is a Lead Data Scientist at the Hanover Insurance Group. His work is mainly focused on applying text analytics and natural language processing to predicting claims and underwriting risks. While having additional experience in both banking and marketing research, he spent most of his career in the insurance industry modeling the impacts of natural catastrophes (hurricanes, earthquakes and extra-tropical cyclones) as well as terrorist attacks, and stress testing capital models. His previous experience includes working in reinsurance in Bermuda, and at Lloyd's of London.

Thank you to our host Chewy! Chewy is currently hiring software engineers and data scientists. Check out their job postings here: https://www.chewy.com/jobs/

If you would like to join remotely, I have added a Zoom bridge as well! https://zoom.us/j/998042103

title: Boston R/Bioconductor for Genomics: Bioconductor, Docker and  Containers (POSTPONED, date TBC)
description:
*POSTPONED*

Bioconductor Docker & Containers

Bioconductor provides a range of options which allow users and developers to perform their analysis using containers, taking away the burden of installing dependencies and system requirements. Containers allow software to be used in a reproducible, reliable and isolated fashion.

Bioconductor also produces containers which replicate their build machines to allow developers contributing to the project to test their changes more aggressively before being put in production. These containers will provide the base infrastructure for cloud/web platforms in the near future. This talk will highlight how to use these containers effectively through docker on your local machine and demo their usage in the cloud.

Nitesh Turaga
Bioconductor Core Team, Roswell Park
https://www.bioconductor.org/about/core-team/
I'm a Senior Programmer in the Core team at the Bioconductor Project. I've been building open source bioinformatics software since 2013, first at the Galaxy Project at Johns Hopkins and now at the Bioconductor Project. I'm passionate about programming, R, and data

https://github.com/nturaga

title: Santa Barbara R Users Group: ymlthis and the R Markdown family
description:
For this event, we are delighted to have the visit of 2 organizers of the LA R Users Group -- Malcom and Zhi! It is a great opportunity to hear more about what they are working on and network among the SoCal R Users groups, including SB R-Ladies.

Malcom is a Ph.D. student in Epidemiology at USC (@malco_barrett).

Title: The YAML problem: Writing and working with YAML with ymlthis

Abstract:
R Markdown is an easy-to-learn tool for reproducible research. Many people, however, bump into problems using YAML, the language that specifies metadata for R Markdown documents. ymlthis makes it easy to write valid YAML by handling the syntax and documenting the majority of YAML fields in one place. ymlthis will help you write metadata for R Markdown, bookdown, blogdown, and more. Let the Shiny add-in create a new R Markdown file for you or work with YAML and R Markdown files directly. ymlthis finally gives you a workflow that is better than trying to find and paste the YAML from the last R Markdown document you used.

Zhi is a Ph.D. student in biostatistics at USC.

Title: How R Markdown family automates the last mile of analytics

Abstract:
What is "the last mile" of analytics? It's the final step that one needs to take to deliver the insights of data and communicate results with decision-makers. R has made it easy for us to wrangle data and build models. With the power of the R Markdown family packages, your analysis can be easily turned into high-quality reproducible documents including reports, presentations, posters, webpages, and dashboards. It requires less time and efforts to create and maintain code, data, output, text in one single document, which leaves you more time working on your code.

Sell you all there!

Julien

title: Zurich R User Group: Web scraping & relational data models with R
description:
Welcome back after the summer break! Join us at Alte Börse for the September edition of the RUG meetup, sponsored by Wüest Partner / Datahouse.

Schedule:

06.15 pm Doors open
06.30 pm Introduction / Welcome
06.40 pm Talks (see below)
07.40 pm Are you hiring? Looking for an R related job? ... or organising an interesting event? Take the stage for one minute. (DM us if you need a slot!)
ca[masked] pm Apéro

*Relational data models with the db package*
Kirill Müller (Cynkra)
Kirill Müller will present {dm}, a new package (https://krlmlr.github.io/dm) that facilitates working with multiple tables. He gives a motivation for using multiple tables in the first place, outlines the features of this package, and discusses future development. The presentation will be interactive with live coding and a script that attendants can run during or after the presentation.

*Tracking Real Estate Project Web Sites with R*
Thomas Maier (Datahouse AG)
Hundreds of real estate project web sites list newly available condominiums and rental flats. This data, however, is not available in an aggregated and chronological format. Our aim was to develop a tool to observe these projects and regularly store their data.
We set up a tool consisting of a front-end to register projects and analyze data, and a back-end with an intelligent background crawling service.
The user interface is powered by R Shiny, connected to a Postgres database and crawling is facilitated using an automated R daemon via a Splash server. The project is deployed with Docker and Shiny Proxy.
The resulting tool enables an efficient collection and observation of relevant projects, automates parsing of target web sites to a high degree and builds up an aggregated and chronological database of newly available condominiums and rental flats.

title: Winnipeg R User Group: Winnipeg R User Group - Meeting #1
description:
Winnipeg R User Group - Meeting #1

The first hour of this inaugural meeting is primarily a Meet & Greet, to find out what local R Users are using R for, and which aspects of R programming people most wish to learn.

The planned activity for the second hour is an (optional) hands-on workshop to help people set-up their R environment (installation of R, RStudio and some key R packages). Please bring your laptop computer if you wish to do this hands-on workshop.

Going forward, we'll have meetings every 2 weeks on Saturday mornings at the Launch Coworking space.

The meeting format is a live coding demonstration presented by one or more group member(s) pre-selected to lead the group in learning R programming applied to a selected subject area, or perhaps learning how to use a specific R package. In most cases, the material to be learned is based on freely available online tutorials or online books.

We plan to allocate sufficient time over the 2-hour meeting duration for attendees to run the presented code (from a Jupyter Notebook) should they wish to bring their laptop computers.

A few local R experts have already volunteered to lead some R learning sessions. We look forward to your active participation in the Winnipeg R User Group.

Wing Kwong
Organizer, Winnipeg R User Group

title: Greater Cleveland R Group: Real-time file import with the vroom package (Jim Hester)
description:
File import in R could be considered a solved problem, with multiple widely used packages (data.table, readr, and others) providing fast, robust import of common formats in addition to the functions available in base R.

However I feel there is still room for improvement in existing approaches. vroom is able to index and then query multi-Gigabyte files, including those with categorical, text and temporal data, in near real-time, parsing at over 1 Gb per second.

This is a huge boon for interactive data analysis as you can jump directly into exploratory analysis without sampling or long waits for full import.

vroom leverages the Altrep framework introduced in R 3.5 along with lazy, just-in-time parsing of the data to provide this improved latency without requiring changes to existing data manipulation code.

I will thoroughly explain the techniques used in vroom to ensure good performance, describe challenges overcome in implementing it, and provide an interactive demonstration of its capabilities.

vroom is on CRAN now, install it with `install.packages("vroom")` and learn more about the package at https://vroom.r-lib.org

title: Portland R User Group: Craggy: Data Vis, Collab, and Discussion about King County Evictions
description:
Come join us in our collaborative data vis activity, Craggy!

We are looking at the King County Evictions Data, a dataset that was compiled for Symposium for Data Science and Statistics 2019. The dataset is available here: http://github.com/pdxrlang/craggy_2019 and it can be installed as a data package into R by following the instructions in the readme.md file.

Whether you're curious about learning about spatial data analysis or about questions about homelessness, we want you to participate! No expertise required.

Feel free to come for part or all of the schedule below. If you just want to share some insights on the dataset, you can just come at 3 PM, or if you just want to work with other people on the data, you can come at 1 PM.

Schedule:

1-3 PM: Dedicated time to in-person collaboration on the dataset. Bring questions/observations you want to work on for the dataset, and we’ll try to find some collaborators to work on it with you. Note you don't have to be an expert, just be curious.

3-4 PM: Presentation & Sharing about the Data. Every group will have an opportunity to give a short (5 min or less) lightning talk about the data. Remember, it doesn't have to be finished and polished, we are just sharing insights about the data and learning from each other.

4-5 PM: Discussion about the data. What were some issues with the dataset? Could we use it to answer our questions about the data? If not, what could have made the datasets better?

Participation in this activity requires adhering to the PDX R Lang Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code_of_conduct/

Note on Parking:

Parking is free on weekends in the Schnitzer Lot next to the Knight Cancer Research Building. To get to KCRB 1011, go up the staircase at the main entrance and head right - it is towards the rear of the building.

Language of the event: R & Slovak
------------------------------------
R <- Slovakia [R enthusiasts and users, data scientists and statisticians of all levels from Slovakia.]
------------------------------------
This meetup group is for Data Scientists, Statisticians, Economists and Data Enthusiasts using R for data analysis and data visualization. The goals are to provide R enthusiasts a place to share ideas and learn from each other about how best to apply the language and tools to ever-evolving challenges in the vast realm of data management, processing, analytics, and visualization.
--
R Community Code of Conduct

A member of the R Community is:

Open: Members of the community are open to collaboration, whether it's on projects, working groups, packages, problems, or otherwise. We're receptive to constructive comment and criticism, as the experiences and skill sets of other members contribute to the whole of our efforts. We're accepting of anyone who wishes to take part in our activities, fostering an environment where all can participate and everyone can make a difference.

Considerate: Members of the community are considerate of their peers — other R users. We're thoughtful when addressing the efforts of others, keeping in mind that oftentimes the labor was completed simply for the good of the community. We're attentive in our communications, whether in person or online, and we're tactful when approaching differing views.

Respectful: Members of the community are respectful. We're respectful of others, their positions, their skills, their commitments, and their efforts. We're respectful of the volunteer efforts that permeate the R community. We're respectful of the processes set forth in the community, and we work within them. When we disagree, we are courteous in raising our issues.

Overall, we're good to each other. We contribute to this community not because we have to, but because we want to. If we remember that, these guidelines will come naturally.

Questions/comments/reports? Please write to the Code of Conduct address: [masked]. (this will email the Board Chair and R Consortium Program manager). Include any available relevant information, including links to any publicly accessible material relating to the matter.

title: Auckland R Users Group (AKLRUG): The Design of Everyday R Functions - Tricks of the Trade
description:
Abstract:

Statisticians are typically not Software Engineers, nor are they taught good practices of software engineering. And yet, Statisticians often take the role of Software Engineers when they program functions in R.

This talk covers major computer programming principles and good practices that help to make R functions intuitive to other R users and our future selves.

As Statisticians try a function from any R package, they face two gaps: first, they try to figure out how to use the function; and second, they try to understand whether their actions with the function get them to their goal.

The role of R programmers is to help Statisticians bridge these two gaps. For example, the second gap is small when the function provides informative feedback about its failure, execution or success. This feedback should be easy to interpret and should match the way the Statisticians think about the function.

The takeaway of the talk is actionable principles which can be applied to the design of R functions.

Speaker Bio:

Harel Lustiger is a Data Scientist at Harmonic Analytics Ltd. specialising in Machine Learning Architecture. His work includes building Machine Learning systems for New Zealand’s largest utility companies and public sector organisations. Harel started his career as an Electronics Engineer and after having a change of heart, moved into Statistics where he worked in Academic research for three years. His research focused on innovative machine learning algorithms for sales purposes and cost reduction.

title: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language): "Official" End of Summer BARUG Meetup
group: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Pizza sponsored by Win-Vector LLC and RStudio.

Agenda:
6:30 Pizza and networking
7:00 Welcome to Microsoft
7:05 Announcements
7:10 John-Mark Agosta - Decision Quality for Data Scientists
7:35 Nina Zumel & John Mount - Practical Data Science with R
8:00 Felix Schildorfer - Predicting Customer Purchasing Patterns
8:25 Ari Lamstein - Behind the Scenes at an R Consortium Project

#############
John-Mark Agosta
Decision Quality for Data Scientists
Borrowing from lessons in model formulation as developed in the field of Decision Analysis, this talk will share some lessons that apply to Data Science projects, and include an interlude on probabilistic model calibration.

#############
Nina Zumel & John Mount
Practical Data Science with R

Practical Data Science with R (Zumel and Mount) was one of the first, and most widely-read books on the practice of doing Data Science using R. We have been working hard on an improved and revised 2nd edition of our book (coming out this Fall). The book reflects more experience with data science, teaching, and with R itself. We will talk about what direction we think the R community has been taking, how this affected the book, and what is new in the upcoming edition.

BIO

Nina and John are the founders of Win-Vector LLC, a San Francisco based company specializing in data science consulting and training. They author a number of R and Python packages, and work in a variety of industries, with organizations both large and small. The Win-Vector blog is followed by data scientists worldwide.

###############
Felix Schildorfer
Predicting Customer Purchasing Patterns

In this presentation I will explain and walk through a model to predict future purchasing patterns for a customer base that can be described by these structural characteristics. The beta-geometric/beta-Bernoulli (BG/BB) model captures both of the underlying behavioral processes (i.e., customers’ purchasing while “alive” and time until each customer permanently “dies”). The model is easy to implement using R's Open Source Library BTYD which was created and is maintained by Daniel McCarthy. For more information see Fader et al. (2010) https://bit.ly/2yynzaK

###############
Ari Lamstein
Behind the Scenes of an R Consortium Project

In this talk I will provide an overview of A Guide to Working with US Census Data (https://rconsortium.github.io/censusguide/), describe how the document came to be, and provide some advice on applying for R Consortium funding for similar projects.

description:
Join Data Science Festival - London in partnership with River Island September 5th, for an evening of 4 lightning talks.

Due to the popularity of Data Science Festival events, we are now allocating event tickets via a random ballot. Registering here enters you into the ticket ballot for the Data Science Festival Event at River Island on September 5th 2019, the ballot will be drawn on September 2nd 2019. Those randomly selected will then be e-mailed a Universe ticket for the event, with the joining details.

If you get an allocated Universe ticket, please bring a copy of your paper ticket or your ticket on your phone to the event to check in with your QR code. Tickets are non-transferable.

PLEASE NOTE REGISTERING ON MEETUP DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU ENTRY TO THIS EVENT.

Please click here to apply for a ticket: https://www.datasciencefestival.com/event/dsf-meetup-with-river-island/

SCHEDULE

6:15: Doors open
6:45: Martin Speed and Gareth Jones
7:05: Sophie Shawdon
7:25: Virginie Bonnefond
7:45: Michael Leznik
8:05: Networking, food and drinks
8:45-9:00: Leave the building

Martin Speed - Safety and Loss Programs Manager at River Island

Gareth Jones - Safety and Loss Analyst at River Island

Summary: As a recently created data science team, our focus is to provide actionable insight quickly. Size gaps on the shop floor that do not currently get replenished represent a £2.5m opportunity and our RFID data can now identify exactly where they occur. Modelling the factors associated with the gaps occurring gave insight into how the issue could be addressed.

Sophie Shawdon - Senior Data Analyst at ClearScore

Summary: Talk Data To Me: Using Machine Learning to Tell Customer Stories. As businesses become more number-driven, how do you ensure that the qualitative data - and in particular what your users are telling you - does not get left behind? In this talk, Sophie will talk through ClearScore's recent work on using machine learning to better understand its customers; and what we learned; and why there's so much value in 'dormant' data.

Virginie Bonnefond - Data Scientist at Hummingbird Technologies

Summary: The recent progress in deep learning is slowly but consistently shifting the paradigm that was followed in remote sensing data processing over the last decades. AI applications are starting to become available for a wide range of applications, from on-board data reduction to fine-grained analytics. Agriculture is one of the areas with the largest social impact of this technological revolution, through a two-pronged strategy. Firstly, AI technology is used to replace the typical flat-rate applications of chemicals with targeted applications only to regions of need, thus alleviating the environmental stress caused by intensive farming practices. Secondly, AI is used to substitute agronomic input across the season, something particularly meaningful in parts of the world where access to agronomical input is limited. In this talk, we are going to present in detail the related topics, while also discussing the technology bottlenecks, limitations and future directions.

Michael Leznik - Head of Data Science at Product Madness

Summary: Bayesian Decision making becoming the widely adopted methodology of choice in the industry. Ability to make your conclusions based on probability distributions instead of arbitrary binary p-values seems to be much preferable when it comes to decision making. The methodology allows to accept null values and estimate statistical power. Using non-parametric Bayesian helps to deal with non-standard models and avoid reduction of statistical power when the probability distribution isn’t normal. The latter is a major drawback when using regular t-tests. Non-binary; significant vs non-significant conclusions provide decision-makers with a plethora of outcome and wide field of possibilities.

title: Data Science Case Studies and Interview Prep: Let's meet and discuss Data Science!
group: Data Science Case Studies and Interview Prep
description:
We will meet every other week and discuss topics in Data Science. I will bring Data Science books and reference material I am currently reading, and projects I'm working on. I encourage you to read up about this week's topics, bring books we can discuss, Data Science questions and your laptops.

Format:
- First 30mins we start with introductions, current data science projects we're working on, and challenges faced
- Then we break into micro groups to brainstorm discuss specific data science topics for an hour
- The core group tries their hand at a data science problem (usually case studies from from Glassdoor interview questions)
- Presentations from the micro groups about their topics

**This week's case study** options include:
- If you are launching a new product (new model of shoes / new headphones etc.) how will you estimate the effect it will have on sales of existing products? (hint: cannibalism math models)

If you have suggestions for topics or would like to present your work ( for > 20mins) to the group please reach out to the organizer by direct message.

Some other good topics to discuss:
- Recent industry research and/or publications from conferences like ICML, KDD, NeurIPS
- Concepts in applied statistics, cognitive computing, graph alrogithms, optimization, evolutionary algorithms, artificial intelligence, machine learning, natural language processing, geoanalytics etc.
- Compare languages & libraries (R, python, Scala, tidyverse, scikit) vs fast prototyping frameworks (H2O, Knime)
- Deployment infrastructure and techniques for your models
- Share your side-hustles, projects, and challenges
- Policy, decision science, and data driven journalism (think Nate Silver election analysis)
- Ethical development of algorithms, and algorithmic bias
- Interpretability, reproducibility, and communication of results

You should join if you are a:
- Practicing Data Analyst or Data Scientist looking to expand your field of knowledge and brainstorm solutions
- Software engineer, analyst, or hobbyist intent aspiring trying to break into Data Science
- Corporation or Non Profit Organization looking for analytics talent
- Product manager or director or policy maker or startup founder interested in discussing how Data Science can help your team
- Artist working with public or personal data in art works
- Anyone intrigued by all this but not specifically categorized :)

If you're interested in data visualization, perception & cognition research check out our other meetup group: https://www.meetup.com/SVDataVizMeetup/

*Red Rock is a local community coffee shop, please support with your purchases. Also it gets really quite busy so plan to arrive before time.

title: Data Science After Dark: Data Science After Dark September 2019 Meetup
description:
Building on the surprising turnout for the Data Science After Dark kickoff in August (~50) I’m happy to announce the Tue, September 17th agenda is ready!

The flywheel for meetup success starts slowly but thank you so much to the 100+ people who have provided input either in person or by the survey, informing our path forward. And thanks to those who have volunteered to speak!

One of the things I have heard many of you say is that you are interested in hearing about what others in the Springfield area are doing with data. This is something I am affectionately calling, “Who’s Who in Data Springfield”, something I hope we can repeat regularly, in addition to the other types of things we do together.

To kick this series off I have invited Sherry Woosley and Matt Venaas, from Skyfactor, a Macmillan learning company subsidiary, out to discuss what they are doing with data at Skyfactor. Skyfactor provides market-leading assessments and benchmarking that empower programs across colleges and universities to identify areas of improvement for maximum impact on student outcomes. Learning about learning, with data – fascinating.

After that, we will take the remaining time to come to some concrete decisions on a plan for how to use this group to learn the tools & methods of data science, and a plan for how we will work together with data to make Springfield a better place. Two other very important things I know you want from DSAD.

Details:
We’ll be meeting at The eFactory (405 N. Jefferson Ave.) on Tuesday, September 17th from 5:30p to 7:00p. Food and drink will be provided while everyone settles in.

RSVP on meetup.com now so you get updates on the meeting room location & any other last-minute details. As we get our wheels turning faster, we will post future events several months advance– for now, please bear with our dust as we try to get out ahead of you. We plan on meeting the third Tuesday of every month - it may help to go ahead and hold your calendar now.

Agenda:
5:30-6:00 – Arrival, Food, Drinks, Networking
6:00-6:30 –Who’s Who in Data Springfield - Macmillan/Skyfactor: Lessons from Surveys of College Students (Sherry Woosley & Matt Venaas)
6:30-7:00 -- Data Science After Dark Learning and Community Service Sub-Groups – What, How, When (Mike West)

Macmillan/Skyfactor: Lessons from Surveys of College Students: After two decades, 500 national surveys, and 15 million survey responses from more than 1,100 colleges and universities, Skyfactor has learned a few things. Sherry and Matt will take a look at how data over the past ten years supports or contradicts common stories about college students and surveys.

About Our Presenters:
Sherry Woosley, Ph.D., is the Senior Director of Analytics and Research at Skyfactor, a Macmillan Learning Company. She drives the research and analytics for 50+ national program assessments as well as other student success-related products. She has delivered more than 100 presentations at conferences and is nationally recognized for her work in assessment, college student transitions, and predictive analytics. She holds a Ph.D. from the University of California, Santa Barbara.

Matt Venaas is a Research Manager on the Analytics & Research Team at Skyfactor, a Macmillan Learning company. In this capacity, he is responsible for survey design and content for 50+ national benchmarking assessments used at colleges and universities. He also is responsible for analyzing assessment data for building educational content, including webinars, conference presentations, and research articles. He has an M.S.Ed. in Adult and Higher Education and a B.A. in Political Science from Northern Illinois University.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Cracking The Data Science Interview
description:
Data Science positions have quickly proliferated among organisations and adds seeking candidates are now abundant on employment websites. While it’s quite new, organisations are crying out for candidates and Universities are only offering tailored programmes in very recent years, interviews are still a large hurdle to get past. Job hunting can feel like a full-time job in itself.

You have to tailor your application, research all the companies you are applying to and later interviewing at and you need the broad domain knowledge to get past the hours of questions.

In this talk, Siobhan would like to breakdown what it is that the data science interview requires and Siobhan will offer some suggested resources to help you prepare. We will cover resume writing briefly.

Following this, we will move into how interviews are structured, broken into four categories. This helps candidates to organise their preparation and to feel confident as interviews unfold without any major surprises.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Siobhan Mcnamara, "The Data Science Interview"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Siobhan Mcnamara:

Siobhan Mcnamara is a data scientist working at Agari, a cybersecurity company in the Bay Area. Originally Siobhan studied Psychology & Economics and had an interest in the intersection of the two. This has lend itself to her current role, they analyze behaviours and use that for identity verification, that is to determine if someone online is who they claim to be. Earlier in her career, Siobhan had a number of research roles in economics and later on learned to code so that she could apply that skillset to a data science position.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Big Data MBA: Driving Business Strategies with Data Science
description:
We have another exciting Data Science meetup.

Many consider data the new oil in that in the way that oil drove the economic growth of the 20th century, data will drive the economic growth of the 21st century. In fact, The Economist recently declared that data is the world’s most valuable resource.

Data Science is the key to deriving and driving economic value from all of this data. It’s become business-critical that organizations become more effective at leveraging data and analytics to power their business models. Organizations must learn to embrace the economics of data to uncover new sources of customer, product and operational value.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Bill Schmarzo, "Big Data MBA: Driving Business Strategies with Data Science"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Bill Schmarzo:

Bill Schmarzo is the CTO for the Big Data Practice, where is responsible for working with organizations to help them identify where and how to start their big data journeys. He's written several white papers, is an avid blogger and is a frequent speaker on the use of Big Data and data science to power the organization's key business initiatives. He is a University of San Francisco School of Management Fellow where he teaches the "Big Data MBA" course.

Bill has over three decades of experience in data warehousing, BI and analytics. Bill authored EMC's Vision Workshop methodology that links an organization's strategic business initiatives with their supporting data and analytic requirements, and co-authored with Ralph Kimball a series of articles on analytic applications. Bill has served on The Data Warehouse Institute's faculty as the head of the analytic applications curriculum.

Bill holds a masters degree in Business Administration from the University of Iowa and a Bachelor of Science degree in Mathematics, Computer Science and Business Administration from Coe College

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Explaining AI: Putting Theory into Practice
description:
We have another exciting AI meetup.

In recent years, the themes of transparency and trust have become increasingly central to the way that humans develop, manage, regulate, and monitor ML technologies. It is clear that now more than ever stakeholders need tools to detect model bias and understand model behavior. At Fiddler Labs, we're building a general-purpose Explainable AI Engine to solve these problems at scale.

In this talk, I will introduce the core ideas behind explainable AI and cover the cutting edge of modern explainability technology that we are harnessing into our core product at Fiddler.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening words
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Luke Merrick, "Explaining AI: Putting Theory into Practice"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Luke Merrick:

Luke Merrick is a Data Scientist working to tackle AI explainability at Fiddler Labs by combining deep theoretical understanding with an appreciation for the challenges of deploying ML in the real world. Luke is a graduate of the University of Virginia with a background in applying machine learning techniques to the pricing of financial assets. He has previously done work in the areas of quantitative finance and insurance tech, and he particularly enjoys tackling the challenges of low-signal time-series prediction problems often found in these disciplines.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: A Data Science Superpower: Empathy
description:
A good data scientist answers quantitative questions as they arise and builds useful tools. An excellent data scientist drives a project to success by understanding larger goals, anticipating unstated needs, communicating effectively across disciplines, and solving the real problems. What key skill explains the difference? Empathy.

In this talk, you'll learn about the three types of empathy and how each plays a critical role in data science excellence. You'll see how quantitative and technical skills can only truly get to value when paired with empathy. You'll learn how to develop specific empathetic skills that will help make your projects successful and your data science career more productive and meaningful.

Agenda:

6:20 pm - 6:30 pm Arrival and socializing
6:30 pm - 6:40 pm Opening words
6:40 pm - 7:50 pm Brad Dolin, "A Data Science Superpower: Empathy"
7:50 pm - 8:00 pm Q&A

About Brad Dolin:

Brad Dolin has been a machine learning engineer, data scientist, data science manager, and CTO at startups ranging from seed stage to $1B+. He has taken an interdisciplinary and cross-functional approach as a Symbolic Systems major at Stanford, as a Fulbright Grantee in Artificial Intelligence, and throughout 18 years of startup experience. In addition to technical leadership in the health and wellness space, Brad is currently pursuing a graduate degree in counseling psychology.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Fundamentals of Machine Learning Workshop
description:
Start learning the basics of Data Science with Python, R, Spark, and Statistics.

This short course covers the fundamentals of data science and tells you about the path that you can follow while you are learning data science. For the ones that are interested in data science but do not know where to start, this daily lecture is for you. You will learn the common coding skills in Python, and acquire knowledge of its data structures, modules, functions, input/outputs, exceptions.

Anyone who is related to data science or thinking to be a part of it can start learning data science with this introductory data science course. Come with your questions, leave with a sense of purpose and direction!

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening

About the Instructor:

Yasin Ceran is passionate about all things data and holds a vast experience in data analysis, mathematical modeling and Apache Spark, and in SQL, Python and R. Since 2013, he has been working at Santa Clara University as an assistant professor in the Information Systems and Analytics department (earlier Operations Management and Information Systems department), teaching applied machine learning, software platforms, and computer networks.

Yasin has worked rigorously on an array of data related projects encompassing data mining, statistics, big data, data science, and data visualization, and is dedicated to sharing his experience and expertise with learners. Apart from data science, Yasin’s knowledge spectrum also expands to cybersecurity and he is an ardent follower of innovative processes and implementations of technologies to defend the world’s digital economies.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: The Ethics of Data Science
description:
We have another exciting Data Science meetup.

As companies and governments turn towards data and machine learning to provide solutions, and interactions with algorithms become a regular part of everyday life, data scientists will be required to make choices in their work which have ethical implications. Ethics is rarely easy, and ethics in data science present special challenges. The ethical impacts of software feature may only become apparent at scale or after a considerable length of time. The collaborative nature of programming and long chain of interactions between programmer and end-user make it difficult to determine where responsibility lies. The recent $5 billion fine levied against Facebook for its role in the Cambridge Analytica breach shows that not taking proper action can be very costly.

Data science is neither good, nor bad, nor ethically neutral. The issues raised by data science, including algorithmic bias, surveillance, microtargeting, and data governance, are too important to be left to specialized ethics reviews boards.

This talk will discuss the impacts of unethical data science, and frameworks and techniques that can be used to guide ethical programming.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening words
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Michael Burnam-Fink, "The Ethics of Data Science"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Michael Burnam-Fink:

Michael Burnam-Fink is a data scientist working at First Republic Bank, where he helps bankers deliver world-class customer service with data-driven insights. He received his Ph.D. from Arizona State University in the Human and Social Dimensions of Science and Technology, where he studied how innovative scientific teams can be developed and the studied the ethics of emerging technologies.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Marketing Analytics and Predictive Modeling with AI
description:
When it comes to moving people and making deliveries, few companies are more widely spread and more widely recognized than Uber. Uber is part of the logistics fabric of more than 700 cities around the world, and whether it's a ride, a sandwich, or a package, they use technology to give people what they want, when they want it.

Uber spends hundreds of millions of dollars in acquisition and retention and we are constantly optimizing the allocation of these budgets and performing experimentation.

We use AI in creative ways to:

- Improve the signal on A\B experiments and have better reads and insights

- Advanced segmentation of customers by propensity to act, churn, open an email

- Cross sell predictions

- Models of resurrection and reactivation

- Natural Language to provide insights on content

- Loyalty programs

In this talk, I will discuss how predictive models are used across these areas:

- How to think and interpret predictive models

- What metrics we use to evaluate these models

- The tools and technologies we use

- Specific case studies in optimization, channel attribution

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening words
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Mario Vinasco, "Marketing Analytics and Predictive Modeling with AI"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Mario Vinasco:

Mario Vinasco has over 15 years of progressive experience in data driven analytics with emphasis in database programming and machine learning creatively applied to eCommerce, advertising, customer acquisition/retention and marketing investment. Mario specializes in developing and applying leading edge business analytics to complex business problems using big data and predictive modeling platforms.
Mario holds a Masters in engineering economics from Stanford University and currently manages a team of data science at Uber Technologies responsible for customer management, retention and prediction. The team conducts advanced segmentation of customers by propensity to act, churn, open email and set up sophisticated experiments to test and validate hypothesis.

Until recently, Mario worked for Facebook as data scientist in the consumer marketing group; in this role he was responsible for improving the effectiveness of Facebook’s own consumer-facing campaigns. Key projects included ad-effectiveness measurement of Facebook’s brand marketing activities, and product campaigns for key product priorities using advanced experimentation techniques.
Prior roles included VP of business intelligence in digital textbook startup, people analytics manager at Google and eCommerce Sr manager at Symantec.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Data Analysis with Python (4 days - 20 hours)
description:
This is a great opportunity to jump into a data science career. We are offering a boot camp to prepare you a data analyst position.

This boot camp is for non-coders who are interested in learning data science or those who have a technical background although are not familiar with the fundamentals of data science.

The course will teach you the fundamental skills of Python, SQL, Statistics and an introduction to machine learning. During our course, you will explore a hands-on experience that will ignite your enthusiasm and confidence to learn data analytics.

Visit our website to learn detailed information about this boot camp. https://magnimindacademy.com/all-courses/data-science-prep/

Fee:
Data Analysis with Python Course has a $599 tuition fee.
For the “Super Early Bird” applicants (August 27 – September 9) the tuition fee is $399.
For our “Early Bird” applicants (September 10 – September 17), the tuition fee is $499.

Schedule:
September 22 – 29 and October 6 – 13
Sundays, from 9:00 am to 2:00 pm

What You’ll Learn in these 20 hours?
1- Python Explore fundamental data types such as strings, booleans, lists, and dictionaries. Learn how to create and organize your code into a clean and professional flow. Learn to analyze data and grow skills to become a data analyst.
2- SQL Discover how databases are structured, how to add and remove data from a database, and how to query a database, as well as, answer questions using aggregations and joins.
3- Probability and Statistics Model real data using common probability distributions and learn how to infer properties during the data generating process.
4- Data Visualization Most importantly, explore python libraries, tools, Pandas, Numpy, and Matplotlib.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Future of AI
description:
We have another exciting AI meetup.

Our speaker Aaron Edell says that: After selling my machine learning startup Machine Box to Veritone, Inc. in 2018, I've had a chance to reflect, research, and experience where and how businesses are spending their money on ML.

This talk is to share my experience navigating the business of applied machine learning, where we saw the most adoption and financial success, and where I would turn my attention to next.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening words
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Aaron Edell, "Future of AI"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Aaron Edell:

Aaron Edell is a veteran speaker and writer on the topics of machine learning, metadata, and content management. He was the co-founder and CEO of Machine Box, Inc., an award-winning startup that builds production-ready machine learning models that anyone can integrate, deploy and scale which was acquired by Veritone in September of 2018. Previously, he helped found and grow Graymeta, Inc., a machine learning and metadata company. Prior to that Edell was at Oracle, Front Porch Digital, Neulion, and SAMMA Systems in various roles from senior solutions architect to product manager. Aaron has published papers on metadata and machine learning and consulted major media and entertainment companies on content management since 2005.

group: Data Science Study Group: South Florida
description:
During this interactive lecture on the foundations of Natural Language Processing, Ben will walk you through the things you need to know, how you can apply them, and the next steps to developing your skills.

Ben Suutari is a Data Scientist at Elucd (https://elucd.com) in New York City, where performs geospatial time series analyses, natural language processing, and production-ready models so that police departments around the United States can better understand community sentiment, and improve community policing efforts. Before starting at Elucd, Ben earned a Ph.D. in neuroscience from New York University where he studied the biophysics of neuronal microcircuits in the hippocampus through experimental electrophysiology and computational modeling. Ben is a South Florida native, and attended Florida Atlantic University for his B.S. in physics where he conducted research on human electroencephalography, medical physics and dark matter detection.

Python has largely become the language of data science, thus, to do successful projects, it helps to be comfortable using Python. Many individuals in our group understand the concepts of data science and machine learning but find it difficult to implement the concepts in code. The goal of this study group is to help individuals achieve a level of comfort coding in Python.

Importantly, data science uses only a relatively small portion of the language. In these casual meetings, we will focus on learning the essentials of Python for data science. We will meet on Thursdays as announced.

description:

Due to the popularity of Data Science Festival events, we are now allocating event tickets via a random ballot. Registering here enters you into the ticket ballot for the Data Science Festival Event at Ancestry on September 10th 2019, the ballot will be drawn on the 6th September. Those randomly selected will then be e-mailed a Universe ticket for the event, with the joining details.

If you get an allocated Universe ticket, please bring a copy of your paper ticket or your ticket on your phone to the event to check in with your QR code. Tickets are non-transferable.

PLEASE NOTE REGISTERING ON MEETUP DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU ENTRY TO THIS EVENT.

Please click here to apply for a ticket: https://www.datasciencefestival.com/event/dsf-meetup-with-ancestry-2/

SCHEDULE

6.00pm doors open
6.30-7:15pm: Dave Rooney
7:15-7:45 pm: Break
7:45-8:30pm: Ben Duffy
8:[masked]pm: Networking & close

Dave Rooney - Using Data Science to understand your family history at Ancestry.com

Summary: With 100 million family trees, 20 billion records and more than 10 million DNA samples Ancestry has a unique set of data needs and opportunities. This talk helps explain how the company leverages the data built over the last 30 years to help people gain a new level of understanding about their lives. Learn about some of those efforts including BigTree, image recognition, NLP, DNA matching, and ethnicity estimation.

Bio: Dave has over twelve years analytical experience in high traffic international websites across a number of online industries including Finance, Travel and Paid Content. He is passionate about telling stories with data and helping companies succeed online.

Ben Duffy - Insights into state of the art robotics and AI technologies

Summary: Ben will introduce the vision of MTank (www.themtank.com), including our most recent work. He'll talk about our main project, 'From Cups to Consciousness', an attempt to teach robots to do increasingly complicated tasks in the real world. For those wanting to get insights into state of the art robotics and AI technologies, e.g. Deep Learning, Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Multi-Modal Methods, Reinforcement Learning, Navigation, Simultaneous Localisation and Mapping (SLAM) and Manipulation/Grasping: Look no further! We'll also open the debate of how we envision the development of AI and robotics over the next few years.

Bio: Co-Founder and Lead Researcher, M Tank. Ben Duffy is a Computer Engineer/Data Scientist with experience in Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing and Reinforcement Learning, from both research and engineering standpoints. Together with the MTank team, he keeps up to date with the very frontier of research within these and related domains. By being fanatically obsessed with both the big picture view and specific details of how AI is progressing, he strives to impart this knowledge to the general public. This also helps him synthesise the necessary techniques to create generally intelligent machines in a multi-decade long pursuit.

title: Kolkata Data Science Meetup Group: Do a real world Data Science project
description:
Do a Data Science real world project.

This is FREE demo class for anyone interested in Data Science. No prior experience required.

In the demo you will learn:
1. Understand the industry need for Data Science (10 minutes).
2. Understand the job market and specific skill set required to succeed (10 minutes).
3. Understand what is Data Science (10 minutes).
4. Learn basics of Python (version 3.7) - See instructions to install Python below (60 minutes).
5. Do a real world project using a real world data set (60 minutes).

What you will need to bring:

2. A willingness to learn :)

Note: Please bring your laptop fully charged a we cannot accommodate charging for everyone.

title: Kolkata Data Science Meetup Group: Do A Data Visualization Project Using Tableau Public
description:
Do a Data Visualization Real World project with Tableau Public.

This is a FREE demo class for anyone interested in Data Visualization. No prior experience required.

In the demo you will learn:
1. Brief overview of Data Science, skill set required and job market. (10 minutes)
2. What is Data Visualization and why it is the "selling point" of your data analysis. (10 minutes)
3. Do a data visualization project with real world dataset using Tableau Public, Windows version (60 minutes).

What you will need to bring:
1. A laptop with Tableau Public (Windows version) installed. Tableau is a data viz software, often sought after skill by big employers. Tableau Public is free for individual and academic purposes. Download and install Tableau Public here: https://public.tableau.com/en-us/s/
We will be using Windows version of the software.

2. A willingness to learn :)

Note: Please bring your laptop fully charged as we cannot accommodate charging for everyone.

For eager learners:

I will send the data set a head of time (usually 2-3 days ahead of the event) and you may complete the project at home. The project can be completed in about 20 minutes if you know Tableau. You will then have the opportunity to present your data viz work, practice your presentation skills and get it reviewed professionally.

Max 5 minutes for the PowerPoint presentation.
You may choose to present alone or in group, in front of the audience or just me. Let me know in the comments below if you want to present and I will have a separate time slot of 5 minutes for you.

Feel free to post any questions in the comments below.
See you soon!

title: Fort Collins Data Science: Steve Malers: Timeseries and Geospatial analysis
description:
Presented by: Steve Malers, Open Water Foundation (http://openwaterfoundation.org)
The Open Water Foundation (OWF) is developing the open source GeoProcessor software to automate geospatial data processing. The GeoProcessor provides a command language to define a processing workflow. The GeoProcessor is inspired by the TSTool software for time series processing. Command files can be run via the user interface or in batch mode, resulting in spatial data output layers and other products. Command editors are provided to facilitate editing the workflow. The software utilizes the open source QGIS Python library and is designed to also integrate with Esri’s ArcGIS Pro. The software automates geospatial processing, allows workflows to be maintained in a version control system, and facilitates collaboration. See the http://software.openwaterfoundation.org website.

title: Data Science Lab: A guide to using asyncio
description:
Asyncio is a library to write concurrent code with coroutines in Python. Introduced in Python 3.4, asyncio makes it much easier to develop concurrent IO-bound code in the language, and has become the de facto standard for cooperative multitasking. It's especially well suited to network applications such as web servers and clients.

Following the success of Andrew Crozier’s blog ‘A guide to using asyncio’, he will be running a workshop on concurrent programming in Python with coroutines and asyncio, including live coded, practical examples.

This event will cover:

- An introduction to coroutines and cooperative multitasking
- Writing coroutines in Python
- Executing code in asyncio
- Asynchronous HTTP with aiohttp

Event Timings:

18:00 Doors open

18:30 Talk starts

19:30 Beer and pizza

20:30 Event close

title: Data Science Lab: Tech Talk: Part 1 of 3 – Making AI safe and explainable
description:
Faculty believes there are three laws of AI that we need today: Explainability, fairness and robustness.
For many real-world applications of AI it is essential that predictions can be explained. This talk, delivered by Data Scientist and researcher Markus Kunesch, will offer explanations into de-mystifying the decisions of black box models. He will discuss why these ‘explanations’ are important, and how they can be achieved.

Explainability is definitely not a “solved” problem and there is a lot of ongoing research. Throughout the talk Markus will point out problems of current explainability methods when applied to real-world problems.

This talk will cover:

Why explanations are important: for decisions that significantly affect people’s lives, being able to explain model predictions is an important part of AI safety. However, in practice the need for explainability goes far beyond this legal and ethical “right to an explanation”. Markus will summarise some of the reasons (including the less commonly discussed and less intuitive ones) and give real life examples.

What an explanation is: this seemingly simple question is crucial but doesn’t have a precise answer. Markus will show what types of explanations are currently possible and in which cases they are or are not helpful.

How explainability can be achieved: Markus will summarise the state of the art for explaining predictions, together with their advantages and disadvantages.

The two most popular ways of explaining predictions of arbitrary black box models, LIME and SHAP. Markus will explain both these methods in detail and show how they work in practical examples.

No AI/coding experience necessary for this talk, however it will be beneficial for data scientists who want to use explainability methods.

Event Timings:

18:00 Event opens

18:30 Talk starts

19:30 Networking, beer and pizza

20:30 Event close

The Faculty Research Lab, in collaboration with top universities, explores the frontier of AI through the publication of research papers and the development of novel technology. We consider our research efforts in terms of two categories: improving the safety of machine learning algorithms (AI Safety) and advancing their capabilities (ML Research).

title: Data Science Dojo – Seattle: Experiment Management for Machine Learning
description:
Details:
An average data scientist (ML Practitioner, AI expert) spends a significant amount of time designing and running experiments (and waiting for them to complete)

This involves one or many of the following:

- trying out various training algorithms
- doing some feature engineering
- changing preprocessing steps to get more homogeneous data
- trying out different types of hyperparameters
- testing data with different datasets

There is a lot that is involved with creating and running experiments, but the only thing that we seem to be equipped to keep track of is the source code of the best performing experiments, and none of the other configuration parameters that actually constitute an experiment.

Because of this, it is quite frequently that we hear phrases like:

“It was working yesterday” - highlighting the commonality in reproducibility of experiment “I don’t remember what the actual scores are, but using feature X didn’t help” - documentation issue “I fixed a bug, but I ran so many previous experiments with that bug”
- code dependency issue
“I am using the same parameters as experiment 4, why is it not working” - reproducibility and documentation issue

In this talk I will go through the typical process that ML practitioners and data scientists follow, taking python and scikit-learn as a use case, and the recurring issues that we are starting to see with these processes.

I will describe the best practices to follow to help document experiments to help reproducibility, and tools and startups that are working on this space to fix the gaping issues that we have for experiment management.

Presenter Bio:
Dr. Rutu Mulkar is the founder of Hunchera, and previously the founder of Ticary Solutions (acquired by Sigmoidal). She received her Ph.D. in Natural Language Processing from USC and has contributed to IBM's Watson system that defeated humans in Jeopardy!

She is interested in solving problems related to Natural Language Processing, specifically - Topic Modeling, Recommender Systems, Information Extraction, Semantics, and Search to name a few, and to apply them to various domains such as SEO and healthcare.

Agenda:
6:00-6:30: Socialize
6:30-7:45: Follow along with the presentation
7:45-8:00 Questions

title: London Data Science Workshop: Data Science hackathon
description:
Hello All Data Hackers

It's time for another data science hackathon, which will be held on Saturday September 7th. The hackathon allows data enthusiasts to come together to form teams and work on competitions from Kaggle (https://www.kaggle.com/) and other data science competition platforms. All levels from complete novices to experienced data scientists are welcome at the meetup. The most important element is your enjoyment of data science.

A huge thank you to Microsoft Reactor who are kindly hosting us for this event at 70 Wilson St, London EC2A 2DB, and, as always, another massive thank you to Jo-Fai Chow from H2O.ai (http://www.h2o.ai/) who are providing us with the pizza for lunch.

If you want to see what Kaggle competitions are currently available, check them out here (https://www.kaggle.com/competitions), alternatively there are also some from CrowdAI (https://www.crowdai.org/challenges?challenge_filter=active) and Driven Data (https://www.drivendata.org/competitions/). If you are a newcomer to data science, please check out the Titanic (https://www.kaggle.com/c/titanic) tutorials -- there will be a Kaggle 101 group during the hackathon where this is often explored. Also, if you know of any other data science competitions or have any other projects don't be shy! You're welcome to work on them and get others involved on the day or through our Slack channel (http://datascienceworkshop.slack.com/), for which auto-enrolment is available here (https://launchpass.com/datascienceworkshop).

Our rough agenda is:
• Arrival from 10.00am for tea/coffee and project discussions
• At 10.30am, form teams to start hacking away at data science competitions
• Break for lunch around 1.00pm
• Start hacking again!
• Lightning talks from 4:30pm.

We look forward to seeing you there — London Data Science workshop organisers

• What to bring: Laptop with an R and / or Python environment.
• Important to know: Please ensure that your full name is recognisable from your Meetup signup, as full names are required for admittance to the venue.

Please note that all participants are expected to adhere to the Microsoft Reactor Code of Conduct (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/reactor/CodeOfConduct).
