title: R-Ladies London: Text Mining Using Tidy Data Principles
description:
(Please, ensure that register to this event at our Eventbrite page
https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/julia-silge-tickets-62444943507, Meetup registration alone won't be valid!).

R-Ladies London have a great pleasure to host Julia Silge (https://juliasilge.com/about/), a data scientist at Stack Overflow. If this is the first time you have heard about Julia then prepare to be impressed. She has a PhD in Astrophysics, been a keynote speaker a multiple conferences and has written a book about tidy text mining (https://www.tidytextmining.com/) together with David Robinson. You are not going to want to miss this!

About the talk
Text data is increasingly important in many domains, and tidy data principles and tidy tools can make text mining easier and more effective. In this talk, learn how to manipulate, summarize, and visualize the characteristics of text using these methods and R packages from the tidy tool ecosystem. These tools are highly effective for many analytical questions and allow analysts to integrate natural language processing into effective workflows already in wide use. Explore how to implement approaches such as measuring tf-idf, topic modeling, and building classification models.

See you all there!

Acknowledgements

Thank you to Mumsnet for hosting us.

El viernes 30 de agosto volvemos a juntarnos, esta vez para aprender sobre visualización de datos en R. Debes traer instalados en tu computador los siguientes paquetes (puedes utilizar este código para hacerlo):

install.packages(“tidyverse”)
install.packages(“datos”)
install.packages(“gganimate”)
install.packages(“gifski”)
install.packages(“png”)

No tendremos conexión a internet, así que la sugerencia es traerlos instalados con anterioridad. Si no has utilizado R antes, puedes revisar la primera parte de este tutorial para ver cómo instalar todo lo necesario: http://bit.ly/tutorial-primeros-pasos-R.

Si es la primera vez que asistes a uno de nuestros eventos, recuerda revisar nuestro código de conducta. Es requisito para asistir estar de acuerdo con él: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

title: Orlando Machine Learning and Data Science: Regression Kriging Model for Improved Environmental Data Science Interpolation
group: Orlando Machine Learning and Data Science
description:
Dan Schmutz is the Chief Environmental Scientist for Greenman-Pedersen, Inc., 1,500-person corporation earning the rank of #56 among Engineering News Record’s top 500 national design firms. His 23-year consulting career has focused on the development and application of ecological and hydrological field assessments, GIS analyses, and appropriate statistical techniques for addressing questions of interest to water resource managers.

In this talk, Dan will present a brief background on the environmental issue of impacts to wetlands and lakes caused by concentrated groundwater withdrawals in the Northern Tampa Bay Area as well as efforts to study the recovery of these natural features following cutbacks in pumping. He was challenged to develop an approach to best predict long-term median water levels and ecological conditions at 684 unmonitored sites (7,900 acres) located in the vicinity of groundwater wellfields. He selected a robust regression kriging (RK) interpolation approach using R to provide estimates of water level and ecological recovery at each un-monitored site. The RK approach considers both auxiliary explanatory variables as well as residual spatial auto-correlation. Other machine learning algorithms may be substituted for “regression” in the “regression kriging” framework, so Dan also will present results using random forest kriging. This hybrid of statistical and geo-statistical approaches may have applications in other problem domains where residuals show spatial auto-correlation.

title: Providence Data Science Project: Topic Study: interpreting your ML model (+ project updates)
description:
Welcome to the Providence Data Science Project's first topic study -- first-timers are welcome!

Machine learning algorithms can be powerful tools for prediction, but they can also be complex and difficult to interpret. A surprisingly big gulf separates "95% model accuracy" from questions like, "Why was this particular image of a dog mislabeled as a wolf?", "What features contributed to flagging a transaction as fraud?", or "How much does choice of major contribute to a student's likelihood of completing their degree program?". If you can't answer such questions, should you really trust your model for making important decisions?

We will start by briefly checking in on ongoing projects to hear about recent progress and current challenges. Then we will dig into SHAP, a recently developed method for interpreting machine learning models such as XGBoost. Discussion will center around the paper (https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.03888.pdf) and accompanying blog post (https://towardsdatascience.com/interpretable-machine-learning-with-xgboost-9ec80d148d27). The more you read, the better our discussion will be!

See our ongoing projects on our Slack channel at https://pvd-data-science.slack.com/.
If you're new, join us at https://join.slack.com/t/pvd-data-science/shared_invite/enQtNTYwMDQ2Njk2MDgyLTA3ZTA1MDUxODYwYTA5ZDk5YjQyODFhYWNmZDEzZWYxOTgzZTExY2Y0ODFiYWFjNjJkNzZiMmVjMzc4MjM0OGU .

Agenda:
7 pm - Introductions and meeting overview
7:05 pm - Project updates and peer feedback
7:30 pm - Discussion: interpreting ML models
8:25 pm - Goals-setting and wrap-up

The meeting will be held at 10 Dorrance Street, Providence RI. Please RSVP by noon on September 9!

title: Providence Data Science Project: Topic Study: interpreting your ML model, part 2 (+ project updates)
description:
Welcome to the Providence Data Science Project's first topic study -- first-timers are welcome!

Machine learning algorithms can be powerful tools for prediction, but they can also be complex and difficult to interpret. A surprisingly big gulf separates "95% model accuracy" from questions like, "Why was this particular image of a dog mislabeled as a wolf?", "What features contributed to flagging a transaction as fraud?", or "How much does choice of major contribute to a student's likelihood of completing their degree program?". If you can't answer such questions, should you really trust your model for making important decisions?

We will start by checking in on a couple of ongoing projects to hear about recent progress and current challenges. Then we will resume our deep dive into SHAP, a recently developed method for interpreting machine learning models such as XGBoost. Discussion will center around the paper (https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.03888.pdf) and accompanying blog post (https://towardsdatascience.com/interpretable-machine-learning-with-xgboost-9ec80d148d27). We will recap our understanding of the paper from last meeting before digging into the details of the algorithm and example applications, so if you missed the last meeting then you are still most welcome to join in the discussion!

See our ongoing projects, explore learning resources, and communicate with group members on our Slack channel at https://pvd-data-science.slack.com/.

title: Learning Data Science in R: Statistics in R: The T-Test & Chi Square
description:
This will be the 3rd class in a Statistics in R cohort. This cohort will start with the bare-bones basics of statistics, and we will gradually work our way up to advanced statistical and data science modeling. I currently work as a Data Science Analyst at Whole Foods Market and will be facilitating this class.

Live Stream Link:
This cohort has in an in-person component but a live stream will be provided. Therefore, people outside of Austin, TX can attend! The link to join this meeting is on my website here: https://kelseyhuntzberry.com/data-science-classes/. Use Google Chrome to connect to the meeting. If you use another browser, you will have to download the entire Microsoft Teams software, which is a large file.

Class Format:
We will have a period of instruction for this class, I will walk you through several examples, and then you will try to run the tests yourself.

Class Content:
In this class we will be covering the most basic statistical test, the t-test. We will cover the one-sample t-test, two sample t-test, the paired t-test and chi square test. We will cover what this statistical test is used for, how to run it, and how to interpret the results. More information can be found at this link: https://kelseyhuntzberry.com/2019/07/29/t-test-and-chi-square/

Software Pre-requisites:
Please bring a computer to class with you if possible. The library will have laptops you can check out, but they cannot install software on these computers.

Please have base R and R Studio installed for this class. Instructions on how to install this software is at this link: https://kelseyhuntzberry.com/2019/07/02/installing-r/.

title: Learning Data Science in R: Statistics in R: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Test
description:
This will be the 4th class in a Statistics in R cohort. This cohort will start with the bare-bones basics of statistics, and we will gradually work our way up to advanced statistical and data science modeling. I currently work as a Data Science Analyst at Whole Foods Market and will be facilitating this class.

Live Stream Link:
This cohort has in an in-person component but a live stream will be provided. Therefore, people outside of Austin, TX can attend! If you use another browser, you will have to download the entire Microsoft Teams software, which is a large file.

Class Content:
In this class we will be covering the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) statistical test. This will include instruction on: One-Way ANOVA, Two-Way ANOVA, and ANOVA assumptions. This test is ideal for experimental analysis. More information can be found at this link: https://kelseyhuntzberry.com/2019/07/29/anova/

Software Pre-requisites:

title: DataCouncil.ai - London Data Engineering & Science: #3 London Meetup: Analytics with Snowplow and Monzo
description:
It's my pleasure to announce the 3rd London Datacouncil meetup, with a fantastic line-up of speakers!

Steve Coppin-Smith, Head of Engineering at Snowplow Analytics will be discussing why your analytics strategy has to be a prime citizen of the delivery process - and what tools you can use to achieve this.

Stephen Whitworth, Engineering Lead at Monzo will talk about how (and why?) to migrate a bank to dbt - and how the migration worked out for them.

Alastair Turner from Pivotal will show us how the pgAudit extension can help provide detailed, specific logging for activity auditing, a key requirement in many environments.

Special thanks to Snowplow Analytics for sponsoring this event (https://snowplowanalytics.com/).

********************
Event details:

6:30pm – Doors open, networking, pizza and drinks

7:00pm - Talks begin

9.00pm - Networking and final beer

********************
Talk 1:
Issue with tracking? Fail that build!

Speaker: Steve Coppin-Smith, Head of Engineering at Snowplow Analytics

Steve's focus is on supporting the Engineering team in making the most of their time and talent. Before venturing in to the world of data with Snowplow, he has spent time as an engineer and team lead on projects in travel, content, communities and education. Steve's key interest is in building high performing, self-managed, scalable engineering teams.

Abstract: Your analytics strategy must be a primary citizen of the software delivery process in order to become a truly data driven business. Successfully collecting valid events is a largely solved problem, but were they a complete representation of the customer journey? Data and software delivery teams need to collaborate on the definition of this journey and better still assert that the product meets these requirements before being given to customers. At Snowplow, we've been building tools to help drive this process and bring teams together.

Talk 2:
Migrating a bank to dbt

Speaker: Stephen Whitworth, Engineering Lead at Monzo

Stephen is an Engineering Lead at Monzo, where he currently runs the Data Engineering team. Before Monzo, he co-founded and ran various machine learning and engineering teams at Ravelin. He lives in London, and is uncomfortable with referring to himself in the third person.

Abstract: Monzo recently migrated their entire analytics function to run on dbt - a tool for managing transformation in data warehouses. In this talk, I'll go through why we chose dbt, the process of how we went about it, what went well, and some of the challenges we faced.

Talk 3:
Activity auditing with pgAudit

Speaker: Alastair Turner, Data Engineering at Pivotal

Alastair has been doing what his wife describes as “He's in computers” for very nearly 25 years. During this time he has coded around all things database from Access to Universe, exploring ways to capture, torture and display data - before going to the dark(er) side as a Sales Engineer. When this allows him the time, Alastair is an occasional contributor to a number of open-source projects.

Abstract: Activity auditing is a key requirement for database technologies in many environments. While Postgres logging can log a lot of detail, parsing details out of logged query text can be painful and it's easy to get it wrong. Join Alastair Turner from Pivotal to learn how the pgAudit extension can help you to provide detailed, specific logging of the session and object activity that matters. With improved management of privilege escalation thrown in as a bonus.

********************
If you'd like to give a talk at one of our future events about data engineering, data science, or data products, we have an open sign up form:
https://davidchia.typeform.com/to/DMHEsm
We'd love to hear your story!

title: Moffitt Cancer Center Bio-Data Club: September Meeting: Introduction to Networking and Linux
description:
The most up to date information for this meeting is available here https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/blob/master/meetings/september_2019/README.md .

The purpose of this session is to learn the basics of Unix systems, to understand how clients connect to servers (basic networking), how we can use linux commands (and regular expressions) to look for specific data, and other useful commands.

For Windows users, they will need to download PuTTY to be able to connect to a linux server. They can either download the MSI (‘Windows Installer’) version, or if they don’t have permission to install software, they can download the standalone version.

Mac users will be able to use the built-in Terminal application.

About the Club: The club is an informal group at Moffitt dedicated to promoting a fun and supportive culture for learning biological data science. Our meetings are intended for all levels of computational backgrounds. We meet once a month in the Moffitt Stabile Research Building on the USF campus. The public is encouraged to attend! More information is available at www.biodataclub.org .

title: Bangalore Natural Language Processing 2.0: AIforLifeSciences: How to leverage AI for life science industry
description:
AI is the most discussed term in recent years and we all know the reason behind it. It’s unimaginable how AI is making everyone's life easy. Same is the case with life sciences industries as well. This meet up is to share and gain knowledge about data science applications in the Life science industry.

FEE: This meetup is free to attend but registration is required.

Agenda:
10:00 - 10:15 Introduction
10:00 - 10:45 How Indegene applies Data Science to disrupt medical workstream
10:45 - 11:15 Applied AI in Pharma marketing
11:15 - 11:45 Natural Language Processing in Clinical Domain
11:45 - 12:30 Problem Statement Discussion and Networking

DETAILS

Talk 1
Speaker: Swayam Mittal

Title: How Indegene applies data science to disrupt medical workstream

Abstract: Explains how indegene applies data science for analyzing and modelling global life sciences and pharmaceutical data for intelligent and intuitive insights with context learning across pre-clinical, clinical and regulatory of drugs and enables intelligent automation in Pharmacovigilance and safety monitoring

Bio: Data Scientist at Indegene's medical technology team with wide expertise in domains such as Natural language processing (text classification, sequence tagging, context learning), computer vision (object tracking, optical character recognition, image classification) and Speech Synthesis with many others using open source libraries like Tensorflow and PyTorch to solve real time problem and product development.He graduated from University of Oxford in the field of Data Science and makes robot in his free time

Talk 2
Speaker: Adarsha Shivananda

Title: Applied AI in Pharma marketing

Abstract: Explains how predictive analytics and AI has transformed the pharma marketing in recent years. Statistics and Analytics is part of Pharma marketing from so many years but it was very unidirectional. But, with the introduction of deep learning, natural language processing, graph databases, and reinforcement learning, the present and the future is looking very promising in the space of customer engagement, personalization and also content creation. In this session, let's explore how to leverage these technologies to enhance customer experience and optimize marketing efforts.

Bio: Senior Data Scientist at Indegene's product and technology team where he works on building machine learning and AI capabilities for pharma products. He aims to build a pool of exceptional data scientists within and outside of the organization to solve business problems through brilliant training programs and always wants to stay ahead of the curve. Previously he has worked with Tredence Analytics and IQVIA. He has worked extensively in the pharma, healthcare, retail, and marketing domains. Recently authored a book on “Natural Language Processing Recipes” with Apress. He is also an adjunct mentor at great learning for ML/AI training program.

Talk 3
Speaker: Prateek Nagpal

Title: Natural Language Processing in Healthcare Domain

Abstract: Focus on how and why Pharmaceutical firms convert unstructured data to a structured format. Further how the data can be leveraged to extract the intelligence to take smarter decisions.

Bio: Data Freak working at Indegene's Medical Technology as a Data Scientist with expertise in Natural Language Processing and Computer Vision. Aims to leverage the power ML and AI to solve business logic and by spreading the knowledge through various training programs and meetups. He has been part of various domains which includes healthcare, pharma and media.

Kindly RSVP on meetup.com or in the Meetup app
We look forward to seeing many of you there!

We thank our Venue Partner Indegene, for supporting the session.

title: Bangalore Natural Language Processing 2.0: NLP in LegalTech Industry
description:
Intro:
Fundamental improvements in AI and NLP in the last decade have led to a significant increase in the number of companies in the LegalTech space. However, though hundreds of promising AI papers are being published, the document understanding problem still remains largely unsolved. Why is this so? This meetup will endeavor to answer this question and understand how State-of-the-Art NLP techniques can be productized in the LegalTech space.

This meetup will also feature a lecture by Professor Partha Talukdar of IISc in which he will present the pioneering work being done by his group in the areas of weakly-supervised information extraction and knowledge graph construction from large corpora.

Klarity:
Klarity(https://www.klaritylaw.com/) is transforming the legal industry by building an NLP contract lawyer. Klarity is an MIT-Harvard Law LegalTech Bay Area startup funded by YCombinator (S18).

FEE: This meetup is free to attend but registration is required.

Agenda:
10:00 - 10:15 Introduction
10:00 - 11:00 How Klarity uses NLP to automatically review contracts
11:00 - 11:30 Deep learning in LegalTech: When it works and when it doesn’t

12:00 - 12:45 Weakly-supervised information extraction and knowledge graph construction from large corpora.
12:45 - 1:00 Closing Remarks
1:00 - 1:30 Networking and snacks

Professor Partha Talukdar, Assistant Professor, Department of Computational Data Sciences IISc and Founder of KENOME (Kenome.io)
http://talukdar.net/

https://www.linkedin.com/in/nishchaln/

title: Artificial Intelligence Meetup (AIM) of Bloomington-Normal: How to leverage Artificial Intelligence for business & personal transformation?
description:
We are happy to host the first-ever meetup session in Artificial Intelligence in the Bloomington-Normal area. We invite data scientists, analytical professional, developers, college students, and professionals who want to switch their career to AI to attend this once-in-a-month event.

This event is an opportunity for you to learn from the speaker, network with like-minded professionals, share your ideas, and learn from each other.

Location:
------------
1413 Leslie Dr,
Bloomington,
IL 61704
Ph: (309)[masked]

Notes:
----------
1. Enter the facility through the Conference Center entrance located at the backside of the hotel
2. RSVP to help us arrange the facility. RSVP closes one day before the event.

Agenda:
-----------
5:30 - 6:00 Networking and refreshments
6:00 - 6:10 Introduction
6:10 - 7:00 Guest speech

Topic Description:
------------------------
Everyone seems to be talking about Artificial Intelligence, but it still seems elusive. We use AI every day often without even realizing that we do. When you type in a phase on the Google search bar or talk to Alexa, you are interacting with an AI system.

Today companies are trying to figure out how to use the power of AI in transformation - to reduce cost, speed things up, and provide amazing customer experiences. Questions that companies may ask themselves are, how do we start and which problems do we address?
Not to be left behind, you as an individual or an employee will also have to transform yourself to meet the AI challenge. Questions you may ask yourself are, how will my job change, and how can I stay relevant?
In this introductory talk, Raj will explore these two threads of company and personal transformation while introducing AI and its sub-disciplines in easy-to-understand terms. You’ll walk away with a simple framework of how to think about AI and get some of your questions on the topic answered.

Brief Professional Bio:
-----------------------------
Dr. Raj Ramesh works with people and organizations that want to transform themselves for the future while leveraging the power of Artificial Intelligence.

Raj has a doctorate in AI and seeks to bring together the complementary strengths of machines and humans to ultimately transform how to incorporate AI in business.

He is also the Chief AI Officer at DataFoundry, where he is spearheading the development of their AI platform and structure.

Raj is also an accomplished writer publishing many articles on the topics of AI and architecture. In his recent book, “AI & You: How to Think, Thrive, and Transform in an Artificial Intelligence Future,” he explores how individuals and companies can best prepare for the new changes AI will bring.

Website & Social Media Links:
----------------------------------------
www.topsigma.com
www.linkedin.com/in/rajramesh
www.youtube.com/rajramesh

title: GigBuzz Zürich: GigBuzz #9: Exbeertise
description:
FinTech Giggers,

Two months ago we introduced you to a whole new networking format, exbeertise. The weather was great, connections were made & the expertise was paid (in kind). Now, let's do it again!

For those of you who just arrived:

exbeertise
/ˌɛkspəerːˈtiːz/

noun
expert skill or knowledge in a particular field paid for with beer.

How does it work?

-> Attendees can offer a particular skill or service they possess or provide:

Some examples of last time

- A crash course on AI
- Tips and tricks to win a start-up competition
- How to survive the fintech frenzy
- CV or LinkedIn profile review
- A survival kit for agile development methodologies at banks

-> Giggers will bid for your "give", and the currency of trade will be beer!

Do you feel like getting some beers in return for your expertise? Drop us a note with your offer and we'll make sure to add you to the list.

Oh and Baris, our great auctioneer, will host the night to make sure all debts are paid and beers are guzzled.

Location to be announced

See you there!

title: GigBuzz Zürich: GigBuzz #10: Perfect Match
description:
GigBuzz #10 - Perfect Match!

No, not a dating show but the latest fresh outing from the FinTech community leaders in Zurich.

Hear from inspiring CTO’s & Founders about their latest and greatest projects, learn what they are currently working on & what profiles they are looking for to add to their team in order to reach their goals. This is your opportunity to mingle with the brightest FinTech experts in town. Who knows, you may even find your next Gig!!

We are thrilled to announce the following confirmed companies: additiv, BlockFactory, Integration Alpha, and Pexapark will be joining us on stage in their hunt for the perfect match.

- Additiv

The leading provider in the field of digitalization of wealth managers. Additiv empowers financial institutions around the globe to deploy class-leading client advisory, servicing and expert tools in wealth and asset management for the digitalization of new and existing business segments.

CEO & Founder Michael Stemmle will tell you how he was able to grow the team to over 120 employees and what profiles he is looking for to shape additiv's future.

- BlockFactory

With a goal of developing high impact solutions that foster blockchain adoption worldwide, BlockFactory has been at the forefront of the industry since 2012.

BlockFactory has developed a technology stack that can be reused in a more modular way for many use cases. With the proven technology and their experienced team, they help to build your blockchain projects successfully. CTO Emeka Mosanya will tell you all about it.

- Integration Alpha

A Crypto Valley Zug based data science company that uses artificial intelligence to build new disruptive business ecosystems, both on blockchain or traditional data science technologies.

Their ferris.ai platform empowers clients to embrace new and data-driven business models, Data Science as a Service. Felix Caprez will tell you more about their wide scope of projects.

- Pexapark

An award-winning Swiss FinTech that is disrupting the renewables industry by facilitating the PPA (Power Purchase Agreement) process for investors and offering them a turn-key solution for their assets. They have multiple interesting open roles that CTO & Co-founder Florian Muller will try to find the perfect match for.

Join us if:

- You want to find out more about the projects these companies are working on
- You are actively or passively looking for a new job at an exciting startup
- You want to meet & interact with key actors in the Fintech scene
- You want all of this while having lots of fun

Agenda

6:00 – 6:30 Opening
6:30 – 8:00 CTOs on stage
8:00 – 8:30 Happy Network

This first edition of Perfect Match will take place at Spaces Bleicherweg, right in the heart of Zurich's financial district.

See you there!

title: Data Viz Jam Sessions: 🍰📊Data Viz and Snacks📈🍩
description:
Come join us for a fun roundtable hangout. See you there! No worries if you're running late-- we do introductions at 12:15.

# Do I need to bring anything?
Nothing specific, but you’ll have more fun if you bring a laptop or a project to work on. It’s a pretty chatty group so you might not get very much done, but it’s nice to come prepared.

# I can’t code… is that okay?
Totally! This is a technical crowd, but you’re welcome to come get inspired.

# What programming languages and tools do people use?
All kinds! We have lots of folks who use R, Python, Excel, Tableau, D3 and many more.

# What do you actually DO at these events?
A whole lot of talking and a healthy dose of goofing off. We usually do introductions at 12:15 and then break out to work on projects, teach each other new things, and show off cool stuff we’ve made since last time.

title: Data Visualization & Analytics Costa Rica: Análisis Estratégico de la Información
description: METODOLOGÍA El programa de capacitación se desarrolla en 2 días, en sesiones de 8 horas cada día. Combina sesiones teóricas y prácticas, que permiten a los asistentes dominar el marco de análisis, así como desarrollar ejercicios para poner en práctica los conocimientos. DIRIGIDO A Profesionales en distintas ramas de negocio, que quieran aprender o fortalecer sus habilidades en análisis de información para aplicarlas a su trabajo diario. CONTENIDOS Día 1: • Preguntas de negocios, Brief, Caso de Negocio y Business Issues: o ¿Cómo se estructuran adecuadamente las preguntas de negocio para análisis? o ¿Cómo se estructura un Brief y un Caso de Negocio? o ¿Cómo se define adecuadamente un Business Issue, que nos permita la búsqueda de respuestas concretas? • Análisis e indicadores estándar: o Lectura, construcción e interpretación de las principales variables, indicadores y análisis usados en los procesos de análisis y toma de decisiones. • Análisis avanzados e interrelación de variables: o Combinación e interrelación de análisis básicos para potenciar las capacidades analíticas y simplificar la obtención de hallazgos Día 2: • Modelo analítico: o Uso de un modelo que facilita la para planeación, creación, organización y comunicación de los análisis. Desde el análisis preliminar de un tema de negocio, hasta el desarrollo del Business Case, implicaciones, oportunidades y recomendaciones. • Storytelling: o Modelo que busca aplicar técnicas de narrativa de historias a través de los números, de forma que permita transmitir los mensajes claramente, captar la atención del receptor de principio a fin, generando más impacto y recordación. • Técnicas de visualización de datos: o ¿Cuáles son las mejores técnicas para visualizar la información? o ¿Cuáles son las mejores prácticas para visualizar los diferentes tipos de datos, las graficas recomendadas para mostrar distintos tipos de datos, aprovechamiento del espacio, etc.?

title: Blent Paris - Artificial Intelligence Meetup: Identifier les tendances mode avec le Deep Learning
description:
Blent.ai

Les tendances sont de plus en plus nombreuses et diversifiées : elles naissent sur un profil instagram, pour être aussitôt adoptées dans la rue. Les délais de conception n’ont jamais été aussi courts car les consommateurs réclament aux professionnels de la mode de nouvelles expériences, toujours plus exigeants et avisés.
Pour survivre, les marques doivent collecter, analyser et interpréter une quantité croissante de données avec toujours plus de réactivité.

Lors de cette conférence, une experte du monde la mode nous donne sa vision sur ces enjeux et nous présente sa startup qui utilise l'Intelligence Artificielle pour aider l'intelligence humaine à créer de la valeur.

Ensuite, un spécialiste du Deep Learning nous présente comment des algorithmes peuvent percevoir et analyser des images.

#computervision #deeplearning #fashiontech #AI

Livetrend propose une solution qui s’appuie sur un système expert exploitant les dernières technologies dans les domaines du traitement et de l’analyse de la donnée.

Speakers

Barbara Maiocchi (Creative Director & Co-Founder LiveTrend)

Entrepreneure, Directrice du Style et de l’Offre, Barbara travaille dans l’industrie de la mode depuis 20 ans. Débutant sa carrière en Italie, elle lance sa marque en 2003, une aventure qui dure 10 ans. Elle a passé les 5 dernières années à Paris en tant que Directrice Créative de plusieurs marques françaises.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/barbara-maiocchi-363a4151/

Samy (Deep Learning specialist, Blent.ai)

Samy est le spécialiste du Deep Learning chez Blent.ai
Il travaille sur plusieurs projets, dont le développement de systèmes d’apprentissage pour les voitures autonomes.
Il est passionné par l'exploration de la façon dont l'apprentissage automatique transforme fondamentalement la technologie, ainsi que par le partage de ses connaissances au plus grand nombre possible.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/samy-kerboua-benlarbi/

title: Artificial Intelligence for Medical Technology: Artificial Intelligence in Hospital Care
description:
We are back after the summer with this 4th edition being hosted by the Antoni van Leeuwenhoek hospital (also known as Netherlands Cancer Institute). As it will take place in the hospital, it will be more clinically flavored and focus on how hospitals are already changing through AI.

There is also a panel discussion for which we ask your input at sign up. We raffle the book Deep Medicine by Eric Topol amongst the ones who pose a question.

We have an elaborate line-up so we start a bit earlier.
The event is free of charge and talks are in English.

Agenda:
17.00 Walk-in, pizzas and drinks!
18.00 Introduction
18.10 Impact of AI on radiology in practice
18.40 From healthcare.hospital import datascience
19.10 Break
19.30 In-house development of machine learning algorithms: predict readmissions
20.00 Panel with the speakers and Irith Kist, Data Protection Officer
20.30 Drinks

Impact of AI on radiology in practice:
Radiologists Erik Ranschaert and Laurens Topff shall give an explanation on what AI actually is and what the impact is going to be on a clinical department such as radiology. Furthermore, they will address the current plans the AVL radiology department has, to improve healthcare by applying AI.

From healthcare.hospital import datascience:
Patrick Gonzalez & Pavlos Papaconstadopoulos are clinical data scientists/engineers and have worked on developing an anomaly detection system to aid radiotherapists in the task of CT annotations. In this talk, they also gave on PyData London 2019, they will tell about the project and give an overview of the challenges, successes and pitfalls of implementing a data science project in a clinical environment.

In-house development of machine learning algorithms: predict readmissions:
Healthcare institutes have started developing their own machine learning models, usually leaving the technical work to external software providers. Bart-Jan will discuss what is necessary to develop models in-house and use them in your healthcare organization. Bart-Jan Verhoeff is internist-nephrologist and CMIO in the St. Jansdal hospital in Harderwijk.

title: R-Ladies Lima: Minería de textos científicos: ¿Cómo analizar publicaciones sin leerlas?
description:
¡Segundo meetup del 2019!

Es hora de reencontranos =) y tenemos a una súper ponente Ph.D. Rocío Joo.

• Lo que haremos:
Se presentará un procedimiento para realizar text mining de artículos
científicos en base a un ejemplo sobre un campo de la ciencia, la
ecología del movimiento. Se hablará de la identificación de los
artículos en la web, descarga de artículos y análisis de datos. Los
participantes podrán también realizar una parte del análisis,
identificación de temas (topic modeling) para un pequeño conjunto de
datos, y realización de nubes de palabras.

• ¿Dónde?
Te esperamos en el Auditorio de la Facultad de Ingeniería Económica, Estadística y Ciencias Sociales (FIEECS) de la Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería.
Dirección: Avenida Túpac Amaru 210, Rímac.
Referencias:
- Altura de la Puerta 5 (Estación Honorio Delgado del Metropolitano)
- Altura del cruce de las avenidas Habich y Túpac Amaru (Estación UNI del Metropolitano)

• Requisitos
Ninguno

• Opcional
Llevar laptop si deseas replicar lo que muestra la expositora.

• Información importante
El proceso de inscripción es el siguiente:
1. Regístrate en este meetup (Dale click a 'asistiré' en este evento).
2. Llena tus datos en el siguiente formulario:
https://forms.gle/S3ZGuaFu8xa7T9Nw8

Debes completar tus datos personales correctamente para poder habilitar tu ingreso.

¡Gracias!

Pregunta frecuente:
P: ¿Los chicos son bienvenidos a las reuniones de R-Ladies Lima?
R: Sí, los chicos son bienvenidos a cualquiera de nuestros eventos. Nuestra misión es empoderar a más mujeres y personas no-binarias para que se involucren en la comunidad R. Por favor, ayúdanos a difundir R-Ladies. Puedes revisar nuestro código de conducta global aquí: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies Barcelona: Road to Data Sciece
description:
Welcome to this new season of R-Ladies Meetups!

As a inaugural event, we welcome Judit Guimera, an invited R-Lady from London, who will guide is through the Road to Data Science.

19:00 - Introduction to R-Ladies Barcelona
19:15 - Road to Data Science, by Judit Guimera

--> Road to Data Science
In this talk we'll discover what Data Science is and which requirements are needed to get a job in it. We will explore what is like to be a data scientist and how to become one as well as what are the different paths that you can take within data science.

--> About the invited speaker
Judit Guimera graduated in Aeronautical Engineering at UPC in 2007 and has been working as quality assurance engineer at Bureau Veritas for about 2 years. After moving to London in 2011, she graduated in Air Transport Engineering at City, University of London in 2013 , when she started her PhD in machine learning and data mining applied to air travel forecasting, for which she is pending to submit soon. Judit has worked at Virgin Atlantic Airways for 2 years as a commercial analyst and she has been working as a Data Scientists at Royal Mail for the past year. She loves coding, taking up any challenge and keep learning!

--> Attending the Meetup
Remember that in the R-Ladies Meetups we expect to have a majority of R-Ladies, so if you are a man you should come with another R-Lady or invite a non-male friend to the Meetup!

Hope to see you all there!

title: la Usina Digital: Open Lab - HR Analytics
description:
La Usina Digital invita a perfiles de HR a integrar nuestro laboratorio de Data Analytics para ámbitos de gestión de Recursos Humanos.

A lo largo de un ciclo de charlas y talleres prácticos se recorrerán e integrarán distintas herramientas y metodologías para el abordaje de Data Analytics en funciones de HR:

-> Los procesos de toma de decisiones basada en datos.
-> La formulación de preguntas y la definición de los objeto de medición.
-> El design thinking como método eficaz para el abordaje a problemas de analítica.
-> Los métodos ágiles como ventaja para las construcciones en equipo.
-> El trabajo con datos de múltiples tipos y formatos.
-> El software open source como soporte herramental a la función analítica.
-> Conceptos fundamentales del análisis estadístico y su utilización en la toma de decisiones.
-> La introducción a conceptos de programación para el trabajo con datos.
-> Herramientas y plataformas de visualización.

La jornada es libre y gratuita, y se realizará a beneficio de la Fundación del Hospital Infantil Dr. Ricardo Gutiérrez por lo que para participar vamos a estar pidiendo el día del evento que traigas algún donativo en forma de:

Leche en Polvo.
Pañales.
Ropa.

Si estás interesado en ser parte de éste espacio de práctica y difusión podes inscribirte a través del siguiente link:

https://tinyurl.com/y6xrgmux

y completar una encuesta destinada a relevar las principales preocupaciones sobre desafíos y problemáticas de la analítica que son de tu interés. Los resultados de las encuestas será participados entre los integrantes del Lab.

A quiénes va dirigido
Esta convocatoria está específicamente pensada para perfiles y roles dedicados a funciones de HR que busquen adentrarse al ámbito de Data Analytics desde la implementación práctica.

title: Thinking Thursday: Thinking Thursday 第三場
description:
19:00 - 19:10 WarmUp
19:10 - 19:50 短講
19:50 - 20:10 中場交流時間
20:10 - 20:30 AI的下一步怎麼走
20:30 - 自由交流

*** AI的下一步怎麼走 ***

講者介紹：
石智翔
曾任職電子業資深統購管理師，現加入 Pattern Hunter 金融 AI 團隊，主要負責標記平台後端開發與產品市場分析。

內容大綱 :
AI 金融產品化的關鍵，是打破工程師與交易員的隔閡 。Pattern Hunter目前正與數間投資證券合作，開發直接從交易員身上學習直覺的 AI 演算法。透過圖像辨識技術，成功將兩者整合，實現人機協作是我們的理念。

貳玖先生
曾任職於工業電腦市場開發經理, 車聯網公司副總，現於AI影像公司服務，背景經驗包含物聯網, 車聯網，人工智慧等實際產業應用。

主題介紹：
AI人工智慧無非是近幾年來最夯的話題。隨著AI科技全面性改變著你我的生活，當大家都認同AI將在以各種型態各種面向滲透世界，這時候該如何搶搭AI商機就很重要，不僅僅要了解產業AI化或是AI產業化，講者將分享在影像分析的AI應用經驗以及探討AI垂直分化的趨勢。

title: R-Ladies Frankfurt: #6: Let’s git together: Introduction to git with github and gitkraken
description:
Dear all,

We’re happy to invite you to the sixth meetup of R-Ladies Frankfurt group on 12th September (Thursday).

In this session, we’re going to explore tools to develop reproducible workflows. In particular, we will learn about git, github, and gitkraken as well as integrate them into our daily workflow. These are an added-value to our data science toolbox, which can facilitate to share our work with our future self and team members.

Frie Preu will guide us throughout this session. Frie works as a data scientist / IT consultant at codecentric. Her journey with R started in 2012 at university. Frie really enjoys data wrangling, writing R packages, and building tools in and for R. In her free time, she volunteers as a core team member for CorrelAid, a data for good network with over 800 members.

Location:
codecentric AG
Kreuznacher Straße 30
60486 Frankfurt am Main

SPECIAL THANKS to codecentric for hosting our event!

What to bring?
(1) laptop with
(2) pre-installed R & RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/)*
(3) pre-installed Gitkraken (https://www.gitkraken.com)*
(4) motivation to meet people, and have fun to create an active R community for women!
*If you’re having issues with installation and set-up, don’t worry! We’re all here to help :)

You’re welcome no matter if you are a complete newbie to R, intermediate or professional R-user.

If you have any suggestions/questions, please feel free to get in touch: [masked]

Also, follow R-Ladies Frankfurt on twitter: @RLadiesFRA (https://twitter.com/RLadiesFRA) and stay tuned for R and R-Ladies related tweets!

Know other people interested in R? Bring them along!
Please only RSVP if you can come!

Looking forward to seeing you!
R-Ladies Frankfurt

title: R-Ladies Newcastle: September meetup
description:
September Meeting – Guest tutorial on linear mixed effects models (LMEMs)

This month's meetup will feature a guest tutorial led by Bodo Winter (http://bodowinter.com/) on running Linear Mixed Effects Models in R. He is a lecturer in Linguistics at the University of Birmingham and an accomplished teacher of statistics and R known for his clear and accessible teaching style.

In the first hour of the meetup, Bodo will lead his tutorial, which will be geared toward somewhat more advanced users of R who are interested in applying LMEMs to their data. However, we invite users at all levels to come follow along and ask questions. Don't be worried about it being too advanced -- this tutorial will be useful for people at all levels!

In the second half, we will have pizza and we encourage you to Bring Your Own Bottle (of any sort of beverage you fancy) to enjoy or to share. This will be a time to talk through practical applications of LMEMs for your own work and ask questions of Bodo and the more advanced users. This will be a great opportunity for people comfortable with statistics to ask more advanced methodological questions *as well as* for people who are more new to LMEMs and R to consolidate the tutorial material.

Timings:
18:00 - 19:00 LMEM Tutorial
19:00 - 20:00 Question and Answers and Pizza

We will be in the Urban Sciences Building again (2.022) and the room will be accessible through the main entrance to the building.

Please arrive with R and R Studio installed on your laptop. If you would like to be loaned a laptop before the meetup, please get in touch with us in the comments below to request one. We’d appreciate being given at least a few days notice.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Data Products and Presentations with R Markdown
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

We will have an event on Wednesday September 18, 2019 from 5:30-7pm
at Allovue (https://allovue.com). We will kickoff our Fall 2019 events with a meetup discussing data presentations and data products using R Markdown, enabling reproducible data analyses. We are also aiming for discussing strategies on structuring your data analysis folders. We are excited to have Ariel Gershman and McKinzie Garrison both from the Biochemistry, Cellular and Molecular Biology (BCMB) Graduate Program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine give presentations.

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you have to make a report or presentation from the results of your analysis with R code, but don't know how!
- If you want to learn about alternative forms of data products with R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA
5:30–5:45 Meet & Greet | 🍪 | Networking
5:45–5:50 Who we are | Announcements | What's next
5:50–6:30 Workshop: Data Products and Presentations with R Markdown
6:30-6:45 Discussion with audience on other questions / resources
6:45–7:00 More 🍪 and Networking

Details on the location:
Allovue (https://allovue.com)
301 W 29th St, Baltimore, MD 21211
(Room 2003, on the second floor at the end of the hall)

Details on parking: Parking is available at R House (https://r.housebaltimore.com) as well as across the street at the police station or in Remington Row’s Garage (entrance on 28th Street, that is paid parking though).

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

title: R-Ladies Lancaster: Tidy Data
description:
This is a beginner friendly session. We'll be working through Chapter 12 of the R for Data Science book. This is available freely online at http://r4ds.had.co.nz . There will be a short presentation and then we'll work through some exercises together. This will involve learning about the functions: (spread(), gather(), separate(), unite(), inner_join()).

Afterwards, we will try these out on our own data. So please, if you can, bring along some of your own data. You could be working on this data at the moment, or it could be something you have used in the past. If you don't have any data, this would be a good learning opportunity to try and find some open source data from the internet.

This will be an interactive session so please bring your laptop. Ideally this should have R and RStudio installed. If you have trouble downloading these, you can use https://rstudio.cloud/. You will also need the tidyverse R package. You might want to install this before coming along to the session. You can do this by running install.packages("tidyverse") in R.

We are in Lancaster University Library - Room C135 and the session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks and soft drinks will be provided.

Antes, novedades! Decidimos renombrar la comunidad de "ArgentinaR" a "Data neRds ES" ¿Por qué?
Somos una comunidad de nerds que les gustan los datos, obviamente, y aunque queremos que crezca la comunidad en toda Argentina, no somos representantes de todas las comunidades que ya existen y están surgiendo a lo largo del país (Como R-Ladies, RenBaires y muchas mas).

Queremos ser una comunidad mas que trabaje codo a codo con todas las otras que están trabajando y por lo tanto dejamos de lado el nombre que tenia una connotación nacional. Sin embargo nuestro objetivo no cambio, difundir conocimiento, apoyar el aprendizaje y hacer crecer la comunidad de usuarios en R en español!

title: R-Ladies Canberra: Statistics on Street Corners by Prof Di Cook
description:
Statistics on Street Corners: Bridging the gap between inferential and exploratory analysis using crowd-sourcing with data visualisation

Plots of data often provoke the response "is what we see really there". In this talk we will discuss ways to give visual statistical methods an inferential framework. Statistical significance of "graphical discoveries" is measured by having the human viewer compare the plot of the real dataset with collections of plots of null datasets: plots take on the role of test statistics, and human cognition the role of statistical tests, in a process modeled after the "lineup", popular from criminal legal procedures. This is a simple but rigorous protocol that provides valid inference, yielding p-values for graphical findings. The procedure can also be used to objectively decide the best choice of graphical display of the same data, for communicating information.

Biography

Dianne Cook is Professor of Business Analytics at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia. She is a world leader in data visualisation, especially the visualisation of high-dimensional data using tours with low-dimensional projections, and projection pursuit. She is currently focussing on bridging the gap between exploratory graphics and statistical inference. Di is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, was recently the editor of the Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, and has been elected as an Ordinary Member of the R Foundation. Several of her students have won the prestigious American Statistical Association John Chambers Software Award, including Hadley Wickham, Yihui Xie, Carson Sievert, and most recently, Monash student Earo Wang.

title: R-Ladies Canberra: Visualising high-dimensional data tutorial by Prof Di Cook
description:
Visualising high-dimensional data

This workshop will focus on parts A and B, and if time allows we will venture into high dimensions, part C:

A. Review basic visualisation and inference with graphics: This part covers making plots using the grammar of graphics and how this fits into statistical inference. We will use the packages ggplot2 and nullabor.

B. Plotting multiple dimensions in a single static plot, adding interaction: The building blocks to viewing high-dimensions are generalised pairs plots and parallel coordinate plots, available in the R package GGally. There are many variations and options that will be discussed, along with making these interactive with the plotly package.

C. Using dynamic plots (tours) to examine models in the data space, beyond 3D: This part will cover the use of tours to examine multivariate spaces, in relation to dimension reduction techniques like principal component analysis and t-SNE, supervised and unsupervised classification models. We will also examine high-dimension, low-sample size problems. The tourr and spinifex packages will be used.

The workshop is interactive, bring your laptop and work along with the instructor, and do challenge exercises.

Materials are designed for an intermediate audience, users who are familiar with R, basic visualisation and tidyverse tools, and who would like to improve their knowledge about data visualisation.

Biography

Dianne Cook is Professor of Business Analytics at Monash University in Melbourne, Australia. She is a world leader in data visualisation, especially the visualisation of high-dimensional data using tours with low dimensional projections, and projection pursuit. She is currently focussing on bridging the gap between exploratory graphics an statistical inference. Di is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, was recently the editor of the Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, and has been elected as an Ordinary Member of the R Foundation. Several of her students have won the prestigious American Statistical Association John Chambers Software Award, including Hadley Wickham, Yihui Xie, Carson Sievert, and most recently, Monash student Earo Wang.

title: R-Ladies Nashville: Package Development in R

Curious about package development, but not sure where to start? This talk is for you! This talk will empower you to start contributing back to the R ecosystem with package development. By the end of this talk, you should know:

- how to make a package,
- test your package, and

Come learn from Jacquelyn Neal, a PhD candidate in biostatistics at Vanderbilt and a data analyst for Virtual Inc. and Jennifer Morse, a biostatistician at Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

Social time starts at 5:30 pm and the talk begins at 6:00 pm.

Thanks to the Nashville Technology Council for meeting space!

title: R-Ladies Cape Town: #TidyTuesday Practical Session
description:
We are very excited to announce a new event format by R-Ladies Cape Town: #tidytuesday. The #tidytuesday initiative was created by R for Data Science (#R4DS) - they release a data set every Tuesday with the challenge to create a unique visualisation based on the data set. We will be doing just that! Bring along your laptop - we will be downloading the #tidytuesday data set released that day (or you could use a previous one if you like) and using it to practice our visualisation skills. We will provide a short script to get you started. You are welcome to work on your own or collaborate, and bring your own data and questions along if you'd like. If you can, please bring something to drink and/or some snacks to share!

From R4DS: "Join the R4DS online learning community in the weekly #TidyTuesday event! Every week we post a raw dataset, a chart or article related to that dataset, and ask you to explore the data. While the dataset will be “tamed”, it will not always be tidy! As such you might need to apply various R for Data Science techniques to wrangle the data into a true tidy format. The goal of TidyTuesday is to apply your R skills, get feedback, explore other’s work, and connect with the greater #RStats community! As such we encourage everyone of all skills to participate!”

We encourage a mix of regular useRs and total beginners to encourage a collaborative co-learning space. Follow #tidytuesday on Twitter for some examples of visualisations created in the past. If you feel up to it, we encourage posting your own visualisation :)

title: EdinbR: The Edinburgh R Usergroup: Identifying Industry Clusters in the Scottish Economy with R and Shiny
description:
Our first meeting after the break will take place on the 25th of September, from 6.00pm, in the Usha Kasera Lecture Theatre (in Old College: https://www.ed.ac.uk/timetabling-examinations/timetabling/room-bookings/bookable-rooms3/room/0001_01_1.264). As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome!

Our two speakers this month have collaborated to interactively explore clusters within the Scottish economy. Gordon Bryden (Assistant Statistician at The Office of the Chief Economic Advisor) & Benjamin Hansson (Assistant Statistician within the Scottish Government) will therefore be discussing:

## Identifying Industry Clusters in the Scottish Economy with R and Shiny

> In this talk, we will discuss our latest efforts to visualise the Scottish Economy as a network consisting of clustered groups of related industries using R and Shiny. We will begin with the basics on networks and clustering before moving on to the algorithm and implementation that we chose to analyse the Scottish Economy. We then give an introduction to R Shiny, a package used to create interactive web apps, and show off our network visualisation and editing app. Finally, we will discuss how we can improve this ongoing project and future applications of our networking efforts in analysing the Scottish economy. We have used the `NetworkToolbox` library for the implementation of the main algorithm. The packages `dplyr` and `tidyr` were used for data manipulation, `plotly` and `igraph` are used for visualisations, and of course `Shiny` is used to build a convenient user interface. All data used will be made available for download, and the code will be shared via GitHub.

title: adminR: R in Swiss Official Statistics: R in Official Statistics: Autumn Meetup
group: adminR: R in Swiss Official Statistics
description:
We are pleased to invite you to our third edition of our semi-annual R meetup, adminR - R in Official Statistics. This time, we meet at the University of Fribourg. The Statistical Office of the Canton of Fribourg sponsors snacks and drinks, the University of Fribourg provides the venue. Thank you very much!

As usual, there will be 🍻, 🍿 and great discussions after the following presentations:

R at the Statistical Office of the Canton of Fribourg
Reto Messikommer

Reto Messikommer introduces the Statistical Office of the Canton of Fribourg and shows how it uses R for various tasks. The Statistical Office is also sponsor of this meetup.

Introducing the Group for Applied Statistics and Modeling
Laurent Donzé

Laurent Donzé is Professor and head of the group for Applied Statistics and Modeling at the University of Fribourg. He introduces his research Group and shows us how they use R in their daily work.

Demographical Long-Term Financing of the Swiss Social Insurances
Layal Christine Lettry

The Federal Social Insurance Office (FSIO) ensures the smooth functioning of the Swiss social security system. Since July 2017, the Mathematics team has worked on developing an R Package which now allows computing annual budgets of the OASI annual reports as well as the financial consequences of reforms such as the Tax Proposal and AHV Financing (TRAF) which was adopted in May 2019 by the Swiss citizen.

Handling of spatial data with R at the Statistical Office of the Canton of Zurich
Katharina Kälin

Handling spatial data with R is straightforward. I will go over a few simple, but powerful tools to get you started using spatial data in R.

title: Scotland Data Science & Technology Meetup: Aberdeen 2019: MSc Data Science / AI Showcase
description:
September's data meet-up is a showcase of projects of students who have just completed their MSc Data Science and AI at Aberdeen University and Robert Gordon University.

Each will have 15 minutes plus time for questions.

----
Talk 1: Danny Fung - "Generating face-like stone images using Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)"
How to generate face-like stone images using Pix2Pix GAN from the extracted face contours.
Danny is an MSc student, University of Aberdeen

----
Talk 2: Somu Kumarasamy, "Prediction of PM levels in Air Pollution"
As part of my academic project, I used the Luftdaten Air quality sensor datasets for analysis. I built a Machine Learning model using these datasets & predicted the PM levels for the next 24 hours. Using the predicted data, developed a visual tool (Traffic light format) to highlight the levels of danger.

Somu, a student at RGU, is an Instrumentation & Control Engineer turned software consultant with good programming skills. He has completed Data Science Masters degree & wishes to get involved in several data prediction analysis.

----
Talk 3: Swarada Adavadkar - "Cryptocurrency Price Prediction"
In the current project, I have used exploratory programming to search for the best predictive model. After an extensive search, I was successful in producing long-term trend forecasts by modelling and extracting complex relationships using Long Short-Term Memory Networks (LSTM).

Swarada is an MSc student at University Of Aberdeen, pursuing a master's in Artificial Intelligence, and was the Student Ambassador for Intel AI Academy.

----
Talk 4 Pauline Cairns "Visualising AIS data "
The location of vessels can be tracked from the AIS data they transmit. Taking this raw AIS data from JSON format, using R programming the data has been analysed, manipulated and then visualised on a dashboard through the use of maps, graphs and a table.

Pauline has recently completed an MSc in IT with Business Intelligence at RGU.

----
Talk 5 : Charlotte Mclean, RGU "Time series analysis of subsea pipeline temperature data."
Charlotte has just finished studying full time at Robert Gordon University, Aberdeen for an MSc in Data Science after a 20 year career in Computer Science and project management. She is ISEB certified in Business Analysis and Prince certified in Project Management. She has worked for small software houses and large companies, such as Legal & General and RBS. She moved to Aberdeen 5 years ago and, after commuting to RBS in Edinburgh for 3.5 years, decided to leave her job to return to study for her MSc full time. She is passionate about data and how data science techniques and artificial intelligence can help society.

Her project looks at the insights on wax appearance in subsea pipelines that could be gleaned purely from temperature sensors. It provides a foundation based on data science techniques for future development in this area.

*****************************
Thanks to MBN Solutions, Data Lab Scotland and Scotland IS for sponsoring this event.

Photo by Hal Gatewood on Unsplash

title: Scotland Data Science & Technology Meetup: The Building Blocks of a Citizen Focused World
description:
This is a joint Scotland Data Science & Technology and Blockchain Scotland meet-up

The Building Blocks of a Citizen Focused World

Date: 4 Sept 2019
Venue: Craiglockhart Campus (parking provided)

Abstract:

GDPR defines an increased focused on encryption and pseudo-anonymization. But many recent data breaches have shown that organisations often have poor practice when it comes to the anonymisation of personally identifiable information. And so, in future systems, we need to focus on the anonymisation the lowest layers of our data gathering, and then identify methods of revealing the information. But how are we going to apply machine learning into infrastructure which use encrypted data? And how are we going to identify individuals within anonymised infrastructures? And how are we going to be able to regulate for consent, privacy and governance?

This Meetup includes presentations on:

Anonymised and Distributed Machine Learning, Adam Hall. 20 mins - https://www.linkedin.com/in/adam-james-hall-1b0229113
Digital Wallets, Will Abramson. 20 mins. https://www.linkedin.com/in/will-abramson-639975120/
The Future of Cryptography: Range Proofs, Mimblewimble, and other Crypto Magic, Prof Bill Buchanan. 30-40 mins. https://www.linkedin.com/in/billatnapier

description:

The first-ever Highlands data science meetup will also be celebrating the opening of The Data Lab's Inverness office.

Speakers:

1. Karen O’Hanlon, Business Development Lab, the Data Lab Hub Inverness - Welcome and introductions programme.
Karen has considerable business development, sales and commercial expertise. Her recent roles include Business Development Manager at the University of the Highlands and Islands and Head of Engagement at Aridhia Informatics. Karen has a wealth of experience in developing and managing innovative collaborations across academia, the NHS and industry, and working with Innovate UK and the Horizon 2020

2.Dr Sara Thomas is Scotland Programme Coordinator for Wikimedia UK - ‘Wikidata: Linked open data the Wikimedia way’
Sara previously held the role of Wikimedian in Residence for both the Scottish Library and Information Council, and Museums Galleries Scotland. Her background is in Events and Volunteer Management, Fundraising, and Digital Skills training. She attended Fortrose Academy before moving to Glasgow in 1997.

3.Robin Huggins, MBN SolutionsAs Director of Academy & Client Services at MBN Solutions - “Data Talent Magnetism”
Rob has spent his career at the sharp end of Talent Acquisition practice for the Data & Technology sectors. Working as Delivery Partner for The Data Lab's MSc. Placement Programme, Rob designed and deployed the highly successful Employability framework that has seen over 200 aspirant Data practitioners placed into Scottish organisations over the last 3 years. In addition to sitting on The University of Glasgow's School of Maths & Stats Industrial Advisory Board and acting as Talent Lead for DMA Scotland, Rob was recently recognised by Data IQ as one of their most influential Data and Analytics practitioners in UK organisations.

4.Dean Mann, BlakesEye - 'AH & I. - The human in artificial intelligence’
Dean is a specialist in analysing complex systems and their associated data. A software/hardware/systems design engineer and engineering manager by experience. Dean is a biologist by training. He has a long track record in leading commercially applied R&D. Current work includes the design and development of ‘The Bridge’ Smart data platform tools and A.I models for healthcare and predictive management of complex assets. He is also developing a novel hybrid blockchain technology, with arange of industrial and healthcare applications. In his company; BlakesEye, Dean has lead 2 successful SMART Scotland Awards extending data science.

5.Graeme Gordon, CEO of IFB - ‘Data Movement and Connectivity’
Graeme has worked at IFB for over 20 years, and provides leadership, strategic vision and direction to the business. IFB is committed to maximising and supporting its customers’ uptime through its connectivity, security and data management offering. Graeme will speak around data movement and connectivity, giving examples of a recent project with offshore connectivity where IFB has enabled smart platforms and rigs to work real-time with data analytics to improve operations and performance.

6.Jude McCorry, Head of Business Development, the Data Lab - ‘UNICEF Data for Children Hub’
Jude has over 15 years experience in Sales and Marketing in the Technology Sector working with B2B and public sector for companies like Dell, Firefly Communications and Xnet Data Storage. Jude has also worked in Academia at Edinburgh Napier University where she set up their commercial arm – The Edinburgh Institute – providing leading-edge practice based executive education to Scottish Executives

This marks the start of our quarterly meetup in the Highlands, and we want to hear from you about how to shape it. If you have any suggestions for topics, speakers, demos, or discussions please get in touch.

title: Predictive Analytics and Data Science using Spark, R, Python: Machine learning measurement and validation in the real world
group: Predictive Analytics and Data Science using Spark, R, Python
description:
Link to register:
https://dataapplab.zoom.us/webinar/register/3015669274034/WN_eCwLBXVnRUaDG8_Z-IXncw

Description:
Data science and machine learning practitioners are waking up to the stark reality that a “99% accurate” AI model isn’t what most of us can expect in the real world. What you build in the lab might not generalize to the field. The data you used in development isn’t accessible to your model in production. The fundamental shape of your ML model drivers changes over time, leading to predictive degradation. And as your model degrades, your stakeholders will ask you to determine why that’s happening, to give them a timeframe for upgrading your model release, and to specify your expectations for avoiding this outcome in the future. (Have fun with that!)

The financial services industry is the domain where probability and risk were coined in the 1700s. (Sorry for the pun. Fully intentional.). In this industry, when data science practitioners make these mistakes, tens to hundreds of millions of dollars are at stake, consumers’ credit records can be affected, and heads roll. For these reasons, the financial services industry (and banking in particular) has put in place repeatable practices to measure model effectiveness and to validate all aspects of these models in ways that is transparent, auditable and explainable.

In this deeply technical and practical discussion, you will learn the practices specific to the best-in-class model performance and validation practices used by financial services practitioners. These practices are completely transferable to virtually every other industry, and the majority (by volume) of actionable business problems, that draw on machine learning approaches. By better understanding how to measure the performance of your models, how to diagnose why they’re working well or poorly, and what you need to do to fix it, you will be able to more effectively set the expectations of your stakeholders, and save yourself a ton of headaches.

Speaker’s Profile:
Robin Way is the founder and President of the decision optimization specialist firm Corios and is a Faculty Member at the International Institute of Analytics. He has over 30 years of experience in the design, development, execution, and improvement of applied analytics models for clients in the banking, insurance and energy industries. Robin wrote the book Skate Where The Puck’s Headed: A Playbook for Scoring Big with Predictive Analytics. He lives in Portland, Oregon with his wife and two sons. In his spare time, Robin plays and coaches soccer and lacrosse, and holds a black belt in taekwondo.

description: We will be using rspark to connect to a distributed database and run queries that are too large to run on a laptop. We'll review the basics of distributed systems and what spark is. Then, we'll take an analysis to completion using the rspark package.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): dtplyr - Speed Meets Readability
description:
Many R users love the dplyr package and broader tidyverse environment. The structure makes writing R code faster, and also more readable.

For many people however, code speed is of the utmost importance. In R, this means working with data.table, which means sacrificing speed of development and readability. What a drag!

That is where dtplyr comes in - and the latest changes make it more valuable than ever before.

Using lazy evaluation and code translation behind the scenes, users can take advantage of dplyr's usability without compromising on speed.

During this talk, we explore dtplyr. What are its pros and cons? The limitations and shortcomings? And what does the future hold for the latest addition to the tidyverse?

Many thanks to Kevin Bolger of ProCogia for volunteering to talk at this meetup! Also a HUGE thank you to the ProCogia team for supporting these events and providing a space to have these meetups!

If you are wanting to have your own meetup to discuss the cool ways you are using R, reach out to Ellis Hughes via Meetup.com!

title: R-Ladies RTP: #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! Work individually or with the group and end the evening by sharing your work.

NOTE: This #tidytuesday event is intentionally being held on a Monday.

We'll explore the Women's World Cup data set available here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2019/2019-07-09. You can read more about the data set via that link too.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:30 pm #tidytuesday
7:30 - 8:00 pm Discussion

This is a great opportunity to meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together!

What should I bring?
Please bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use. If you have time, please look at the data set beforehand and think about some questions you'd like to answer with it.

Where will it take place?
Cocoa Cinnamon Lakewood

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Hamburg R User Group: Gaußprozesse und probabilistisches Programmieren in R
description:
Hi everyone, we are happy to announce our next meetup. As usual the meetup will be open for all including newcomers and beginners. This time the presentation "Gaußprozesse und probabilistisches Programmieren in R" will be held in German.

The agenda for this meetup is:

18.30 Open Doors
18.50 Welcome / AOB
19.00 "Gaußprozesse und probabilistisches Programmieren in R - Teil I" - Christoph Schmalhofer (InNuce Solutions)
19.30 Break
19.45 "Gaußprozesse und probabilistisches Programmieren in R - Teil II" - Christoph Schmalhofer (InNuce Solutions)
20.30 Getting ready for 🍕 & 🍝 at https://via-toselli.de/

** Gauß Prozesse und probabilistisches Programmieren in R

Gaußprozesse sind überall.

Gaußprozesse sind mächtige probabilistische Modelle für Supervised Learning. Die Vorzüge haben Herlands, Neill, Nickisch, Wilson (2018) schön formuliert:

"Gaussian processes (...) can flexibly model non-linear functions, seamlessly extend to multidimensional and irregularly sampled data, and provide naturally interpretable parameters. Perhaps most importantly (...) Gaussian processes do not in general overfit the data."

Im ersten Teil werde ich in einer RStudio Session mit einfachem Code und vielen Plots ein intuitives Verständnis aufbauen.

Im zweiten Teil stelle ich das R Paket GauPro und die GP Unterstützung in Stan vor. Interessant ist dabei auch das unterschiedliche Vorgehen in einer funktionalen Sprache (R) und einer probabilistischen Sprache (Stan).

Zum Abschluss spreche ich kurz die weiterführenden Themen "Deep Gaussian Processes" und "Neural Processes" an.

About the speaker: Christoph Schmalhofer ist Software-Entwickler/Architekt bei InNuce Solutions in Hamburg. Er hat Philosophie und Physik studiert und arbeitet seit 20 Jahren in der Software-Entwicklung. Er hat unter anderem ein OODBMS, Kreditrating-Software und einen Fahrzeugkonfigurator mitentwickelt.

title: R-Ladies Los Angeles: Advanced R Book Club Part 3b: Object Oriented Programming
description:
The LA West R Users Group and RLadies LA are teaming up for a book club series focused on Hadley Wickham’s ‘Advanced R’!

Where: UCLA Charles E. Young Research Library, West Classroom (Room 23167)

Directions: Look for West Classroom (Room 23167) after entering the library. Consider public transit or rideshare if you live nearby since you need to pay for parking. UCLA Parking Structure 5 & 3, both are walking distance to the library. See www.transportation.ucla.edu/campus-parking/visitors

When: 10 am, Saturday, September 7th

Why: "The book is designed primarily for R users who want to improve their programming skills and understanding of the language. It should also be useful for programmers coming to R from other languages, as help you to understand why R works the way it does." - Hadley Wickham

Come join us for coffee and #rstats as we tackle the book’s sections one at a time. Each book club session will have a leader to guide the discussion, and we encourage everyone to take a look at the material beforehand. The full text of the book is online for free at https://adv-r.hadley.nz/, and there's an exercise answer guide at https://advanced-r-solutions.rbind.io/.

Here’s the schedule:
• Foundations - August 3, session leader was Amanda Tilot
• Functional Programming - August 10, session leader was Amy Tzu-Yu Chen
• **OO Programming - split over August 24 (Base Types, S3, and R6) and September 7 (S4 and Trade-offs), session leader will be Daniel Jacobs**
• Metaprogramming - split over September 21 (Ch 17, 18, 19) and October 5 (Ch 20, 21), session leader will be Emil Hvitfeldt!
• Techniques - split over October 19 (Ch 22, 23) and November 2 (Ch 24, 25), session leaders will be Jake Kramer and Malcolm Barrett respectively!

Advanced R dives deep into how R works as a language, and we highly recommend joining us for the first two sessions if you’re relatively new to R. We’re also looking for discussion leaders for the later sections of the book, so please reach out to Amy or Amanda if interested!

This is a bring-your-own-coffee series, but we'll try to provide something sweet. As we're cohosting with the LA West RUG, all R users are welcome! Lastly, we expect all attendees to abide by the RLadies Code of Conduct, available here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la.

See you there!
Amanda & Amy

"This is the perfect book for someone who wants to understand R at a level slightly deeper than necessary for an analyst and less than a base R contributor. If you're interested in programming language design or at looking under the hood of R, this book rocks. " - Goodreads review

**To become more involved**
Invite yourself to our SoCal R Users Slack group and join #adv-r-bookclub for discussions: http://bit.ly/laerug
Check out more events: laocr.org/

Advanced R dives deep into how R works as a language, and we highly recommend joining us for the first two sessions if you’re relatively new to R. We’re also looking for discussion leaders for the later sections of the book, so please reach out to Amy or Amanda if interested!

This is a buy-your-own-coffee event, so let's support Literati Cafe. As we're cohosting with the LA West RUG, all R users are welcome! Lastly, we expect all attendees to abide by the RLadies Code of Conduct, available here: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-la.

See you there!
Amanda & Amy

"This is the perfect book for someone who wants to understand R at a level slightly deeper than necessary for an analyst and less than a base R contributor. If you're interested in programming language design or at looking under the hood of R, this book rocks. " - Goodreads review
