title: Köln R User Group: R Benutzer Treffen Köln / R user meeting in Cologne
description:
For organisational reasons: please only RSVP "yes" if you actually plan to attend and don't forget to update your RSVP if needed!

Otherwise: same place, same time, same spirit :)

Agenda:

18:00 Talk

Federico Marini - iSEEing is believing: exploration of sequencing data, made easy and efficient

Recent technological advancements in the life and medical sciences have allowed these fields to evolve into quantitative disciplines.
Gene expression profiling with RNA-sequencing, protein quantification via mass spectrometry, high throughput imaging are complex assays that often require advanced methods for processing and generating actionable results. Notably, large and heterogeneous datasets need specific techniques also for the exploration, and I found that an effective combination of interactivity and reproducibility is essential for doing this properly.

Interactive visualization can be a key player in this regard: for quality assessment of often noisy multivariate data, for hypothesis generation and exploration, for the visualization of results, as well as for the efficient communication of findings. Another essential aspect is that often the scientists generating the primary data might not be well versed in programming, notably increasing the iterations required to extract insight out of it.

Many of these aspects are common in other fields than bioinformatics, and I will present in detail the functionality of a Bioconductor software I co-developed, iSEE (http://bioconductor.org/packages/iSEE/) as an application. Leveraging point-and-click user interfaces with guided tours, I will show how users can efficiently explore high-dimensional datasets, automatically retrieve the code for the generated output, and learn (by doing) how to generate compelling scientific figures.

About Federico (https://federicomarini.github.io/, @FedeBioinfo):
I am a Postdoctoral Virchow Fellow at the Center for Thrombosis and Hemostasis (CTH) and at the Institute of Medical Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Informatics (IMBEI) in Mainz, Germany, where I can sit at the interface with many other disciplines and focus on translational bioinformatics. My research interests involve the development of methods and software for interactive and reproducible research, bringing together the fields of bioinformatics, statistics, genomics, and biology.
I love working in the R programming language, and with software from the Bioconductor project, where I also contributed some packages over the years (pcaExplorer, ideal, iSEE).

18:45 Talk

Markus Nu - Deploying Shiny Apps in an Enterprise Context - ShinyProxy as an open source alternative

After building your R Shiny app, you most often want to show it to others.
Although Shiny Server provides an easy way to get started, in an enterprise context you soon reach a point where you want your users to authenticate and your applications to scale.
ShinyProxy is an open source alternative to Shiny Server Pro, which has built-in functionality for user authentication and authorization, tracking and most importantly no limits on concurrent usage!
In this talk we will see an end-2-end deployment with ShinyProxy, from running ShinyProxy as a docker container on a single machine, setting up an InfluxDB user tracking endpoint up to deploying your R Shiny application via ShinyProxy.

About Markus: Markus is working as a Data Scientist at OBI next trying to discover interesting and meaningful patterns in data. He is excited by all kinds of data, big or small, logs or surveys, images or text. Prior to joining OBI next, he worked as a research analyst in market research. He studied Political Science (B.A.) and Survey and Data Science (M.Sc.) at the Universities of Mannheim and Maryland.

Pizzas and drinks will be provided.

title: R-Ladies Seattle: Code Reviews! Learn how to review code & submit code for review
description:
How do you review code from a data science project? Often, the goal of code review is to ensure that new code is free of bugs, efficient, well-documented, and maintainable. Code review is also an excellent opportunity to learn from others and get feedback on your work. However, practices vary widely from academia to industry and standards are mostly non-existent.

At this event, we will hear from R-Ladies members about best practices for code review, how code review is conducted in their workplace, and then we'll practice code review in small groups.

Speakers:
Lauren Wolfe, Research Data Specialist at Fred Hutch
Carrie Bennette, Principal Quantitative Scientist at Flatiron

We are looking for R-Ladies members to share code that they'd like feedback on for the group exercise. Please comment in the event discussion thread if you have code you'd like to bring to the meeting.

Pizza & refreshments will be provided by Fred Hutch.
Please feel free to bring children if childcare is unavailable.

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday｜Domain Adaptation 的數學理論推導
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
主題：Domain Adaptation 的數學理論推導

摘要：
機器學習在實務上常會需要解決 Domain Adaptation 的問題，也就是說，訓練模型所使用的資料，和實際上模型要預測的資料，它們的分佈是不一樣的。近年來（2014~）有相關多的研究，針對 Domain Adaptation 的應用情境提出很多解決方式，但其基本的數學原理仍然大同小異。本次演講會針對 Domain Adaptation 的數學理論做比較詳細的介紹，主要會參考這篇論文：
https://www.alexkulesza.com/pubs/adapt_mlj10.pdf

講者介紹：
Mark Chang
人工智慧及數學的愛好者，喜歡從數學理論的角度來切入人工智慧的研究。

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday｜Make your own Kriging interpolation algorithm with python
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
主題：
Make your own Kriging interpolation algorithm with python
用 python 寫出自己的 Kriging

講者：
蔡瑞發 Data Scientist @Gogoro

大綱：
Kriging 是地理統計中常用的 interpolation 演算法，利用空間中量測點間的變異量與距離的關係來預測相近位置的觀測值。在資源有限的的情況下，常幫助地質學來了解未知地域的地質特性。除了在地質學上，這樣的空間預測演算法也能有其他應用。在大數據時代，現有的工具（例如 ArcGIS, QGIS）能處理的資料類型受限。這次的演講來分享如何利用台灣地震開放資料與 python 的套件（numpy geopandas scipy rasterio）來設計自己的 Kriging interpolation algorithm。內容包含數學推導與程式範本。

title: WiDS-Sthlm:  Women Data Scientists Stockholm: Data Scientist Late Fika
description:
TEMA: REDUCING THE GENDER GAP

We meet, take a coffee, we get to know ech other, mentor each other and this week we can talk about:

WOMEN, OBSTACLES IN THE WORKFORCE:
The challenge of getting and keeping women in tech and data science This challenge goes beyond educational exposure though. Recruitment and attrition seem to be other obstacles causing the numbers of women in the field to drop.

The NCWIT report questions the common belief that the lack of gender diversity among qualified applicants is the top reason for the unbalanced ratio of men to women in the tech industry. According to a LinkedIn study, more women are hired as software engineers outside of technology, comparing the 20% hired in technology to the 32% hired in healthcare and 25% in banking.

Gender diversity could be unbalanced based on the way a company recruits for a position. Many recruiting efforts rely on referrals to determine top candidates. However, according to the NCWIT report, a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York found that 64% of employees recommend candidates of the same gender as themselves. And in a 2015 study, Looksharp found women are three times less likely to seek tech internships than men. These internships are another common way to recruit for STEM related positions.

Once women do break into the field, keeping them poses another problem.

According to the NCWIT, women are two times more likely to quit their job than men in the high tech industry (41% to 17%). However, the primary reason for leaving is not due to family obligations, contrary to popular belief.

In the same NCWIT report, it was found that 49% of the women who left their SET job remained in the industry. In fact, 22% of these women went on to create their own company.

WHY ARE WOMEN LEAVING?
A study by McKinsey and Lean-In asked similar questions of women in the workforce as a whole. They found that women are four times more likely than men to feel like they have fewer opportunities than men in the workplace.

Looking at the computing and tech fields, 30% of women in SET positions felt isolated or stalled, according to the NCWIT report. The feeling stems from “having a limited number of important or special assignments that are highly valued by high-level managers,” and “not understanding the ‘unwritten rules’ or norms of [a] company or department,” which can be linked to a lack of mentorship and support. According to a Hewlett study from 2014, this type of dissatisfaction is found more in women ages 25 to 34 who are fresh in the field.

During a roundtable discussion, Women in Data Science, the data scientist of Data-Mania, Lilian Pierson said, “Women need to understand what opportunities are available to them, what those opportunities involve, and what the quality of life looks like for someone in this role.”

This can’t be achieved without proper support. Mentoring has had a large influence in closing the gender gap in tech and data science.

In the Women In Data interviews, almost all of the interviewees mentioned a mentor that they relied on for encouragement to remain in the field, whether a supportive family member or a co-worker open to questions.

Sarah Aerni, the data scientist at Pivotal, said in the roundtable discussion, “… One of the main challenges is that mentors are most effective when they can see themselves in those they are helping. I actually do not believe that this means women should only be mentored by women. Instead, I think it has to do with the path that you have taken, so mentors can recognize and help with challenges they faced themselves.”

RESOURCES:
Women in Machine Learning and Data Science (WiMLDS) – A community hosting events, conferences and workshops for women interested in machine learning and data science. (USA)

Women in Big Data Forum – A LinkedIn forum aiming to increase the diversity in the big data field through mentoring and peer engagement.

(source: November 2018, www.betterbuys.com/bi/women-in-data-science)

title: MiraiLabs | Data Science Workshops: From prototype to production
description:
3-hour workshop with a break, followed by some drinks and snacks.

IMPORTANT:
As this workshop has a limited capacity, we would like to make sure that we limit the amount of "no-shows" as much as possible. In order to achieve that, we...
i) ...have a second mandatory registration on Eventbrite.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/from-prototype-to-production-registration-70891746121

So if you are planning on joining, make sure to register there as well, else we can unfortunately not count you in.

ii) ...ask anyone who has signed up but cannot attend, to please de-register from the event as early as they know. Similarly, if the additional detailed description below doesn't attract you, you may want to consider giving up your spot this time.

Schedule:
4:15 pm - doors open
4:30 pm - welcome / workshop
6:00 pm - short break
7:30 pm - end of workshop / closing remarks
7:40 - 9.00 pm - Apéro at the bar (Community Salon)

Workshop details:
We will discuss and demonstrate typical steps for moving a prototype into a production setup, along with associated challenges and benefits.
We will give an overview of possible components, tools and technologies involved in a target state, while showing some of them in action with a simple, concrete use-case example.
The example will be used throughout the workshop, to illustrate a working, end-to-end case of moving a prototype into production.

Although the main topics are technology agnostic, for a practical illustration we will be referring to specific open-source software and tools. In particular, the example will make use of the R programming language and the GitHub platform, however, experience with R is not required to follow the workshop.
The workshop has been structured such that it is easy to follow, with the
key elements and steps demonstrated live. Materials will be made available and shared online:

https://github.com/miraisolutions/MiraiLabs

and we do hope to give you all the necessary ingredients to try things out yourself after the workshop!

description:

Für zukünftige Treffen seid ihr herzlich eingeladen Themen vorzuschlagen, wenn ihr von irgendwelchen coolen Datensätzen wisst.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On behalf of BUND Ostwürttemberg (https://www.bund-ostwuerttemberg.de/bund-ov-aalen/)
we will be evaluating public particulate pollution sensor data. The analysis might include looking for strongly affected areas, finding interesting trends, correlations, etc. The obtained insights and visualisations will subsequently be published on a website and presented to BUND.

The Meetup will take place in the Innovationszentrum Aalen (Anton-Huber-Straße 20, 73430 Aalen). The Room will be clearly signposted.

It would be great if you could bring your laptop with the following software already installed:
* Tableau Public - https://public.tableau.com/de-de/s/download

title: Lyon Data Science: L'importance de la normalisation en analyse de données
description:
Pré-requis : statistiques descriptives (moyenne, variance, z-score, médiane, distributions, Gausienne, etc)

L’analyse de données est une tâche complexe, composée de multiples étapes successives : lecture des données, pré-traitements, extraction des caractéristiques, modélisation des caractéristiques et évaluation. La normalisation des données semble appartenir majoritairement à l’étape de pré-traitements, ce qui est faux, puisqu’on peut la retrouver aussi dans des tâches haut niveau comme la détection d’anomalies, l’apprentissage automatique, l’apprentissage profond, les tests statistiques, etc. De plus, l’étape de pré-traitements est souvent vue comme contraignante et peu valorisante. Il n’en est rien, car en réalité, c’est ici que se joue une grande part de l’efficacité de toute la chaine de traitements. La valeur ajoutée du data scientist est rarement dans l’étape maSuperMethode.apply(), mais plus souvent dans la manière de présenter les données à cette méthode.
Dans cet exposé, nous verrons dans un premier temps l’intérêt de la normalisation, puis les différentes manières de normaliser, et enfin les applications.

Quentin Barthélemy

title: Burlington Data Scientists: The Mathematics of Neural Networks
description:
Dr. Kirn will dive into the mathematics of neural networks, establishing the foundations for machine learning using neural networks. She will use a classification problem as an example throughout to keep the math contextualized with a practical problem. This talk will significantly expand on Dr. Kirn's previous lightning talk. Topics will include the purpose of the cost function, as well as valid choices for the cost function; the purpose of the activation function and valid choices; using neural networks for classification vs regression; the backpropagation algorithm; and a brief foray into Bayesian networks.

About the speaker:

Dr. Malina Kirn is a Principal Technical Architect at Cox Automotive. She has also worked at NASA, the Large Hadron Collider, Palantir, Opower, and MIT Lincoln Lab, and has a PhD in Scientific Computing from the University of Maryland College Park.

title: Data Science Brest: Ocean Data Lab-SeaScop:  Harmoniser et optimiser le format IDFmulti-résolution
description:
Le jeudi 12 septembre à 18 h30 à La pointe du Deolen Locmaria Plouzané
L'équipe de Ocean Data Lab vous présentera une proposition d'harmonisation de format de données avec le format IDF multi-résolution déjà utilisé avec le logiciel SEAScope qui permet d'indexer puis visualiser et analyser à moindre effort tout types de données satellite, modèles ou in-situ.
Les problématiques liées à la conversion au format IDF pour les données existantes, ou l'optimisation du format IDF pour une lecture rapide seront abordées.
Ce sera également l'occasion de découvrir le magnifique site de la pointe du Deolen, de se retrouver et de déguster des produits locaux et artisanaux à base de houblon fermenté.

https://www.oceandatalab.com/b6f50301-c770-4df5-b52e-485722e0abc5

title: Data Science Brest: Le machine learning et l'IA au service de la santé
description:
Quelle place pour le machine learning et l'intelligence artificielle dans le secteur de la santé? De l'analyse d'image à l'étude de dossiers médicaux, les usages potentiels sont nombreux : diagnostic, orientation thérapeutique, ...

Nous vous proposons de venir échanger de ces usages lors du prochain Meetup Data Science Brest.

18h45 - 19h30 : Le machine learning au service de la santé, Gwenael GUILLARD, Intradys (http://intradys.com/)

L'intelligence artificielle accroit chaque jour son empreinte sur les systèmes de santé à travers le monde et les transforme de manière profonde et radicale. Les progrès des applications à base d'IA bénéficieront certainement à l'ensemble des acteurs : le patient, les professionnels de santé et les organismes payeurs. Toutefois, ces mêmes acteurs peuvent se montrer réticents à l'utilisation de l'IA et certains challenges restent à surmonter.

19h30 : Networking

title: Data Science Brest: Transfert d’apprentissage pour la reconnaissance des scènes  acoustiques marines
description:
Le groupe Data Sciences Brest relaye les activités de l'initiative ALLOHa qui pourraient vous intéresser.
Attention nouvel horraire ! 12 h-14 heures, apportez votre lunch box !
Le prochain atelier Machine Learning le mardi 24 septembre 2019
"Reconnaissance de scènes biologiques en acoustique sous-marine par transfert d’apprentissage" Présentation par Dorian Cazau et Paul Nguyen
Le lien vers les ateliers précédents:
Lien Github: https://github.com/amlb/amlb.github.io

ALLOHa c'est quoi?
ALLOHa Advanced Living Lab For Ocean Hacks -Data -Driven Innovation and Services for Ocean Sustainability est une initiative portée par le Campus Mondial de la Mer. Lieu d’innovation collaborative, ALLOHa a pour vocation de réunir d’une part, la communauté scientifique en Sciences Marines et en Data Sciences et d’autre part, les entreprises qui innovent dans ces domaines.

Pourquoi relayer les ateliers dans le groupe?
Le programme Alloha propose différents types d'ateliers sur la thématique de la Data Science à fréquence régulière (Ateliers sur le Machine Learning les 15 jours, des Dominos Lectures techniques pour ceux qui veulent creuser le sujet, ...)

En quoi consistent ces ateliers?
- 1 speaker
- qui répond à une 1 question concrète et appliquée autour du machine learning
- en utilisant 1 méthode de machine learning
- sur 1 dataset formatté avec benchmark

Dans cet atelier, nous mettons l’accent sur :
- une compréhension intuitive et graphique de la théorie et de ses équations
- les méthodes de la famille des réseaux de neurones !
- le partage des données et des codes
- la diffusion de bonnes pratiques en data sciences, de centralisation des codes et données, eg notebook python, benchmarking.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: September R-Ladies Community Meetup
description:
Join us for our September R-Ladies Community Meetup, where we’ll get to know one another and generate ideas for R-Ladies Dallas in 2019 and beyond. Come with your ideas for talks, speakers, workshops, book clubs, study groups, mentorship, projects, fundraising, and organizing, or just a willingness to get to know your fellow R-Ladies!

We are also looking for speakers that would like to give talks ranging from 20 to 60 minutes at future meet events. If you have an idea for a talk that you'd like to give, come prepared to pitch your idea to the group.

Agenda
6:30 - 7:00 Networking w/ other tech meetups (Free pizza, soda, & beer)
7:00 - 7:15 Welcome and Introductions
7:15 - 7:45 Lightning talks
7:45 - 8:30 Planning for R-Ladies 2019 and beyond

There will be no formal technical talk at this meeting, but we will dedicate approximately 30 minutes of the session to attendees that have R analyses or packages they would like to share. The rest of the time will be dedicated to networking and planning future R-Ladies activities.

Several other meetup groups will be meeting in the same venue, so this will be a great space for networking. You will also (of course) have an opportunity to connect with other R-Ladies members during that time. Oh, and did I mention the **free food and drinks**? Our hosts at Improving have generously provided free pizza and assorted beverages, including coffee/tea, soda, water, and BEER. :)

Feel free to reach out to Sydeaka if you have any questions!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About R-Ladies Dallas

R-Ladies Dallas welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling. Our non-profit, civil society community is designed to develop our members' R skills & knowledge through social, collaborative learning & sharing. Supporting minority identity access to STEM skills & careers, the Free Software Movement, and contributing to the global R community!

A local chapter of R-Ladies Global, R-Ladies Dallas exists to promote gender diversity in the R community worldwide. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R. As a founding principle, there is no cost or charge to participate in any of our R-Ladies communities around the world.

Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies, and by being respectful of the fact that this event is primarily for women/non-binary/female-identifying individuals.

We expect all attendees to abide & be governed by our community code of conduct. Please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct.

title: R-Ladies Belo Horizonte: R Intermediário - We R Ladies
description:
INSCRIÇÕES ESGOTADAS!

Objetivo do curso:
Melhore suas habilidades de análise de dados em R.

NÍVEL DE HABILIDADE: Básica

O que você vai aprender neste curso?

• Importação de bases de dados – txt, csv, xlsx, arquivo online
• Empilhando e juntando base de dados (joins)
• Limpeza de base de dados
• Manipulação de bases de dados
• Loops Inteligentes
• Estatísticas Descritivas
• Utilização do operador pipe (%>%)
• Visualização de dados

Este curso é para você?
Se você é mulher (cis ou trans) e quer aprender a programar, de forma simples e, principalmente, com uma facilitadora mulher, vem miga que este curso é para você <3

O que você precisa levar?
Se possível, levar um computador e filtro de linha. Antes de iniciar o curso você receberá um guia com as informações sobre o que precisa ser instalado e como fazer isso.

Precisa ter algum conhecimento prévio?
Sim, o ideal é que você tenha participado do nosso curso de Introdução ao R, ou tenha alguma noção do básico do R.

Vai ter certificado?
Vai sim, todo mundo que fizer o curso terá direito a um certificado de 6h.

Quem é a facilitadora?
Ana Carolina Dias - Mestre em Estatística pela UFMG | Membro do Stats4Good (Statistics for good) e Analista Estatístico.

Carga horária:
6 horas.

Quando?
14 de setembro, de 9h às 16h30.

O curso é gratuito?
Sim, mas pedimos a colaboração de 1kg de ração de gato ou cachorro.

Ficou alguma dúvida?
É só enviar para [masked] ;)

title: R-Ladies Milan: #Tidytuesday workshop
description:
Here we are again with a new event & hope you had a great summer holiday!
As like previous workshop, we planned another tidytuesday event.
It is a practical workshop to sharpen data wrangling skills, we are going to explore a Tidytuesday dataset in groups or individually.
What is Tidytuesday?
TidyTuesday is a weekly data project with the goal to use your data processing skills to summarize and arrange data for making meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem. The intent of Tidytuesday is to provide a safe and supportive forum for individuals to practice their wrangling and data visualization skills. For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post: https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt
A new dataset is released on Github every Monday (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) and anybody is welcome to explore data & publish its results on Twitter.
Agenda:
19:00 - 19:15pm Meet and Greet
19:15 - 20:15pm Data exploration & analysis
20:15 - 20:45pm Discussion
This is a great opportunity to meet other other data lovers, improve your Data science skills and build up your GitHub/Twitter/data science portfolio!
Who is this for?
New and experienced data scientists are welcome! You are free to use other programming languages such as Python.
What should I bring?
Bring your own laptop (fully-charged!) and all learning materials you want to use.
Do to limitation of the seats, please RSVP Yes, in case you are sure that you can join us, thanks for your collaboration and Can't wait to see you all!

title: R-Ladies New York: The Superlearner with sl3 and Parameterizing R Markdown Reports
description:
**Meeting location: 1300 York Avenue, Second Floor, Room A-250**

Our speakers for the night will be Elizabeth Mauer and Kat Hoffman from Weill Cornell Medicine. Elizabeth will be talking about parameterized reporting in R Markdown. Kat will be discussing the Superlearner machine learning algorithm using the sl3 package.

Agenda:
6:30-6:45 pm Introductions and Social
6:45-6:55 pm R-Ladies New York Announcements
6:55-7:25 pm Parameterized Reporting in R Markdown
7:25-7:55 pm Become a Superlearner: Using sl3 to build ensemble learning models
7:55-8:00 pm Community Announcements
8:00-8:30 pm Networking

Title: Parameterized Reporting in R Markdown

Abstract: Elizabeth’s talk will focus on how to take customizability of your R Markdown reports to the next level with the help of parameters. Parameters allow the user to change certain aspects of their report without having to go back and make changes within the R Markdown document itself. This is very helpful when producing the same report but under different conditions/assumptions.

Title: Become a Superlearner: Using sl3 to build ensemble learning models

Abstract: Kat will discuss ensemble machine learning in R. Ensemble models combine multiple models to create a stronger overall prediction model. She will give an overview of ensemble learning methods and the packages available in R. She will then focus on understanding and using one algorithm for ensemble learning – stacking, or superlearning – through the R package sl3

Bios: Elizabeth Mauer and Kat Hoffman are research biostatisticians in the Division of Biostatistics and Epidemiology at Weill Cornell Medicine. They engage in short-term and long-term bio-statistical consultations with investigators throughout different departments of New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center. Elizabeth received her Masters from Temple University and her Bachelors from the University of Scranton (home of the show The Office!). Kat received her Masters from the University of Michigan and her Bachelors from the University of Detroit Mercy.

title: R-Ladies Austin: Book Club: Invisible Women Data Bias In a World Designed for Men
description:
Hello Ladies!

We are excited to announce our next book club book, Invisible Women: Data Bias in a World Designed for Men. This book was suggested to us by one of our R-Ladies Austin members Sue!

You can find the book here: https://www.amazon.com/Invisible-Women-Data-World-Designed/dp/1419729071

As of today all copies at the Austin Public library are out so must be a good read! Check back later or place a hold on a copy here: https://austin.bibliocommons.com/item/show/2062372067

Should be a great read and engaging discussion over a brew--coffee or beer or tea at Thunderbird! More info on the book below. We hope to see you there!

From Amazon about the book: "Data is fundamental to the modern world. From economic development, to healthcare, to education and public policy, we rely on numbers to allocate resources and make crucial decisions. But because so much data fails to take into account gender, because it treats men as the default and women as atypical, bias and discrimination are baked into our systems. And women pay tremendous costs for this bias, in time, money, and often with their lives.

Celebrated feminist advocate Caroline Criado Perez investigates shocking root cause of gender inequality and research in Invisible Women†‹, diving into women’s lives at home, the workplace, the public square, the doctor’s office, and more. Built on hundreds of studies in the US, the UK, and around the world, and written with energy, wit, and sparkling intelligence, this is a groundbreaking, unforgettable exposé that will change the way you look at the world."

title: R-Ladies Floripa: 4º R-Ladies Floripa | Desigualdade de gênero e cor no Mercado da Tecnologia
description:
Olá, Ladies!

Chegamos ao 4º encontro da comunidade R-Ladies em Floripa :)

O que é a comundade R-Ladies?
O R-Ladies é uma organização mundial, com a missão de promover a diversidade de gênero na comunidade R e no mercado da tecnologia como um todo. O foco principal do R-Ladies é promover encontros onde possamos construir uma rede global e colaborativa de líderes, mentoras, aprendizes e desenvolvedoras para facilitar o progresso individual e coletivo de mulheres em todo o mundo! <3

Nesse encontro teremos uma proposta um pouco diferente: fazer uma breve apresentação, seguida de uma Roda de Conversa sobre a Diversidade de Gênero e Cor no Mercado da Tecnologia.
O propósito da Roda de Conversa é discutir sobre a desigualdade de oportunidades e compartilhar as vivências e desafios enfrentados por diferentes mulheres nesse cenário; além de trocar experiências sobre ações possíveis para promover a Diversidade. Um momento para refletirmos onde estamos e onde queremos chegar!

Como faço para participar?
O evento é totalmente gratuito e todas são muito bem-vindas! Basta confirmar a presença aqui no meetup para garantir sua vaga ;)

Quando e onde vai ser?
Nosso 4° encontro vai acontecer no dia 24 DE SETEMBRO, terça-feira, às 18:30h e será na UFSC, no Miniauditório do CSE.

Qual é a programação do evento?
- Conhecendo o R-Ladies - Glenda Larissa de Mello | Organizadora do R-Ladies em Floripa.

- Palestras Relâmpago

- Tecnologia e diferenças sociais - Larisse Pontes | Antropóloga - Doutoranda PPGAS/UFSC.

- Roda de conversa sobre Desigualdade de Gênero e Cor no Mercado da Tecnologia.

O que são Palestras Relâmpago?
Espaço reservado para você falar brevemente sobre o que quiser! Pode pedir e oferecer vaga de emprego, apresentar comando mágico, divulgar seu evento, produto ou serviço, técnica nova, incentivar motins para destruir o patriarcado, qualquer coisa mesmo, pode usar sua criatividade neste momento... acabou os 5 minutos? Palmas e próxima!
Não se acanhe e prepare a sua Palestrinha pra gente se conhecer melhor.

Não deixe de participar, inscreva-se!!

Vem de carro?
Ofereça carona no evento e já chegue acompanhada ;D

Você pode ajudar na divulgação do evento convidando mais mulheres a se juntarem à nossa comunidade. É só seguir nossa página no meetup
( https://www.meetup.com/pt-BR/rladies-florianopolis/ ) ou o inspara ficar por dentro de todos os eventos.

Se quiser colaborar com a organização dos próximos eventos, oferecendo palestra, lugar para receber o evento, coffe break, sugerir temas ou qualquer coisa, entre em contato com a gente!

Formas de contato:
E-mail: [masked]
Você também pode entrar em contato com as organizadoras iniciando uma conversa no evento ou inbox aqui no próprio site do meetup.

Realização e colaborações:
R-Ladies Floripa

description:
En esta tercer reunión tenemos como objetivo explorar y aprender lo básico de Git, Gtihub y Rstudio de la mano de Edgar @nekrum, Maribel, Marisol @emmsol y Joana @joanux810.
Unete con tu laptop y aunque no es necesario saber R es conveniente instalar R (https://cran.r-project.org), RStudio (https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/) y Git (https://git-scm.com/book/es/v1/Empezando-Instalando-Git) antes del taller.
Te esperamos para aprender juntxs :)

title: R-Ladies Concepción: MySQL y R - Sistema de gestión de bases de datos relacional (2ª Parte)
description:
En nuestro quinto taller aprenderás a utilizar MySQL, sistema de gestión de base de datos relacional (RDBMS) de código abierto, basado en lenguaje de consulta estructurado (SQL).

Te esperamos el próximo jueves 29 de Agosto a las 18:30 hrs. en el Auditorio del Instituto de Investigación Pesquera (INPESCA). Colon 2780, Talcahuano.

Para el taller, es importante que tengan sus propios computadores, y que descarguen R project desde este link ->: https://dirichlet.mat.puc.cl/ y descargar la versión gratuita de R Studio ->: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/
Además, para este taller sera necesaria la descarga de MySQL, desde el link -> https://www.mysql.com/downloads/

Si es la primera vez que asistes a uno de nuestros eventos, recuerda revisar nuestro código de conducta. Es requisito para asistir estar de acuerdo con él: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

¡No dudes en consultarnos cualquier duda, te esperamos!

title: R-Ladies Concepción: RMarkdown
description:
En nuestro sexto taller aprenderás a utilizar la librería RMarkdown. En términos sencillos RMarkdown es un procesador de texto que ofrece además la posibilidad de incluir trozos de código desde R (u otros formatos). El principal beneficio de esta herramienta es que permite trabajar en un sólo documento tanto la redacción del contenido narrativo de reportes de investigación, como también la construcción y presentación formal de resultados de análisis estadísticos.

Te esperamos el próximo jueves 05 de Septiembre a las 18:00 hrs. en la Sala A302AC en la Universidad del Bío-Bío.

Para el taller, es importante que tengan sus propios computadores, y que descarguen R project desde este link ->: https://dirichlet.mat.puc.cl/ y descargar la versión gratuita de R Studio ->: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/
Además, para este taller sera necesaria la descarga de MySQL, desde el link -> https://www.mysql.com/downloads/

Si es la primera vez que asistes a uno de nuestros eventos, recuerda revisar nuestro código de conducta. Es requisito para asistir estar de acuerdo con él: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish

¡No dudes en consultarnos cualquier duda, te esperamos!

title: Qatar Data Science, AI,Machine learning & Analytics Meetup: 3 Day Bootcamp on Data Science in Doha
group: Qatar Data Science, AI,Machine learning & Analytics Meetup
description:
Program objective
Build foundational skills in Data Science, Business Analytics and predictive modelling through the right mix of in-person and online training.

What will you learn
1. Understand the basics of R and R Studio
2. Learn the basics of statistics, data exploration, and data preparation
3. Understand the basic terminologies around Business Analytics, Data Science, Machine Learning & Artificial Intelligence
4. Learn to build business solutions with in-depth understanding and application of key regression modeling techniques
5. Learn to build business solutions with in-depth understanding and application of key classification & segmentation techniques
6. Experience real-life problem solving with real business data sets in the form of case studies and Capstone Project.

Skills you will build
Predictive modelling, Clustering, Forecasting, R programming, Data exploration, Data preparation, Statistics, Regression

Price: $999.00 /per person
Enroll Now: http://bit.ly/2V64Td1

Who should take this program
The course is suitable for you if you are one of the following:
•A business manager/ consultant who wants to leverage Data Science in his industry/ functional area.
•A mid-career professional who wants to build skills in Data Science for career growth
•An entry-level professional or a student who wants to build his career in Data Science.
•An academic who wants to get started with Data Science

What are the pre-requisites?
1. You should be a graduate
2. You should have basic knowledge of MS Excel.
This is a foundational program, hence there is no prior programming experience required to attend the program. However, if you are completely new to programming then you must go through the “Basics of Programming” module before you attend the classroom session.

Program Features
•3 days (30 hours) of in-person training with 5 hours of instructor-led live online training supported by self-paced modules
•CleveredLab, a platform that helps you learn by applying newly acquired knowledge in the classroom and later. The platform helps you experience the nitty-gritty of problem-solving and building the solutions.
•LEAP (Learning Environment for Analytics Professionals), an e-learning platform that provides the flexibility of learning anytime, anywhere and makes the learning convenient.
•Learning with real-world business problems: The program gives you an exposure to the actual business problems with real-world datasets from multiple industries.
•Sessions delivered by industry experts from organizations like Accenture Management Consulting, Barclays, Standard Chartered and HDFC bank.
•Program and pedagogy developed in collaboration with business leaders, domain experts and functional SMEs with rich experience in business consulting.
•Certificate of Participation and Project Completion Certificate
•A mix of in-person and live online sessions supported by self-paced content to provide the maximum value to the participants
•1 live online session for technical/career mentorship with a senior data scientist with 10+ years of experience.
•1 live online sessions for Q&A and discussions on case studies
•1 live online session for support on Capstone projects
•8 weekly quizzes
•3 capstone projects to expose the real world challenges to participants.
•Become a part of the community of Data Science enthusiasts and experts and solve your business problems. Know More -http://bit.ly/2V64Td1

title: Western Mass Statistics and Data Science: Research Bytes at Mass Mutual: Data provenance + monitoring of production models
group: Western Mass Statistics and Data Science
description:
Come join us at 5:30pm for refreshments and two short talks at 6:00pm.

Barbara Lerner (Mount Holyoke College): Making Provenance Work for You

To be useful, scientific results must be reproducible and trustworthy. Data provenance---the history of data and how it was computed---underlies reproducibility of and trust in data analyses. Our work focuses on collecting data provenance from R scripts and providing tools that use the provenance to increase the reproducibility of and trust in analyses done in R. Specifically, our ProvTools use data provenance to document the computing environment and inputs and outputs of a script's execution, support script debugging and exploration, and explain differences in behavior across repeated execution of the same script. Use of ProvTools can help both the original author and later users of a script reproduce and trust its results.

Adam Fox (MassMutual): Effective Monitoring of Production Models

Abstract: Data scientists can deliver significant value by automating or enhancing business processes using predictive models. There is also opportunity for these models to cause damage by producing invalid output as a result of data errors or population shifts. These systems must therefore be carefully monitored for problematic data. In this talk I will present MassMutual's model monitoring infrastructure and invite discussion on best practices

title: LA R users group: LA East R Users: Deep learning with R & Run Python in RStudio with reticulate
description:
Talk 1:
Speaker: Huiyu Deng, PhD candidate in Biostatistics, University of Southern California
Title: A gentle Introduction Using R for Deep Learning

Abstract:
Do you know that R can also develop and evaluate deep learning models using Keras, one of the most popular deep learning libraries in Python? In this presentation, I will introduce the steps to set up the platform to run Keras in R and give you an overview of the concepts of neural network (NN) and deep learning models such as convolutional neural network (CNN). In the end, we will analyze a dataset using the Keras package.

Talk 2:
Speaker: Jo Hardin (@jo_hardin47), Professor, Pomona College
Title: reticulate: running Python within RStudio

Abstract:
A quick google search can quickly bring up many arguments on both sides of the heated Python vs R debate. I don’t take sides in that conversation, but I do recognize the value of knowing both languages and the power of being able to use one language inside software designed for the other. Whatever computational environment is used to execute instructions to the computer, it can be illuminating to see different implementations of the same syntax producing the same results, or alternatively, implementation of different syntax producing the same result. In this talk, I discuss running Python in the RStudio environment. I provided a series of examples in R Markdown chunks (both Python chunks and R chunks). I include details for those working with Python in R for the first time.

Code of Conduct: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

Timeline:
6:30: Socializing
7:00-8:00: Talks
8:00: Socializing

Address:
Room 115/116
USC
2001 N. Soto St.
Los Angeles, CA 90032

Parking: Parking is free in the metered spots on the east side of the parking lot after 5 PM

Invite yourself to our Slack group: http://bit.ly/laerug
Ask us any questions by email: [masked]
Find our previous talks on GitHub: https://github.com/laRusers/presentations
Follow us on Twitter: @la_Rusers
Check out more events: https://laocr.org/

title: R Generation: Creating beautiful analytics dashboards in R
description: The dashboard is an excellent tool for presenting performance measures such as business KPIs as well as general trends and patterns in data. Dashboards can also serve as a canvas from which to tell a story with your data. In this workshop, we will use the flexdashboard package to build an elegant dashboard that contains interactive data visualisation components along with other nice features such as gauges and dials.

title: Oxford R User Group: October OxfordRUG meeting
description:
Agenda:

6:00 pm: Julia Clark -- A step by step guide to "How I produced my first Shiny app", followed by a discussion of use cases with examples

7:00 pm: Pizza!

###

Shiny (https://shiny.rstudio.com/) is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R. In this meetup, Julia will tell us how to create your first Shiny app, followed by a discussion of various use cases of Shiny.

###

Oxford RUG is thrilled to be sponsored by Mango Solutions. Thanks to their generosity, there will be pizza from Franco Manca after the meeting. When RSVPing, please let us know whether you will be staying for pizza (so we get a sense how much pizza to order).

title: Vancouver Data Visualization: [x-post] Data and Visualization meet Sustainability Entrepreneurship
description:
We are happy to co-host another meetup with the "Data Science for Social Good" group.

To make it easier to keep track of attendees
▻ PLEASE RSVP HERE ◅
https://www.meetup.com/meetup-group-vancouver-data-science-for-social-good/events/264409115

__WHAT'S EN4S?__
We are proud to hold an evening of presentations in support of the Entrepreneurs for Sustainability (EN4S) initiative. EN4S is a month-long series of events gathering fresh and bright minds for tackling sustainable energy issues, taking place in September & October 2019 in downtown Vancouver.
See more details about the entire EN4S initiative here: https://en4s.bcsea.org

__AGENDA__
5:30 Doors open
6:00 Intro
6:10 Presentations
7:30 Networking & Mingling

__PRESENTATIONS__

► LEAH HANVEY
▻ Better Urban Planning for the Planet

Leah is a Business Development Manager at Urban Logiq (www.urbanlogiq.com - our host venue) and former research advisor for GLOBE Advisors in Vancouver. Leah is a former Advisor to the federal Minister of Small Business and Tourism and Government House Leader. Leah was also a technical analyst in financial modeling for Deloitte, completed an exchange at the University of Zurich in banking and finance and worked at the Vancouver Economic Commission performing economic research.

► ANTHONY PAK
▻ Assessing the environmental impact of building materials

Anthony is the Principal of Priopta which provides parametric Life Cycle Assessments (LCA) for buildings. Those assessments enable architects, engineers, and developers to design buildings that use materials with significantly lower embodied environmental impact. A wide range of material design options are being analyzed and visualized to help the customers quickly compare material options and make informed decisions. He loves to visualize interesting environmental data and will be showcasing a few data visualization projects relating to buildings, energy policy, climate solutions, and food impacts.

► YULIANA PROENZA
▻ Exploring historical Geothermal Data: GIS and 3D Visualization of Mount Meager

Yuliana is a Geologist working in the mineral exploration field since 2006 at various deposits across Canada at different stages of exploration and development. For her Master’s thesis she was compiling and evaluating historical exploration data available for the Upper Lillooet geothermal area, associated with the Mount Meager volcanic complex, located 150 kilometres north of Vancouver. She provided a data foundation and 3D visuals for that data, which includes geochemical results for springs and well fluids, consolidation of general geology and structural mapping, and drilling data including collar locations, survey deviation data, downhole lithology and temperature measurements.

► ELENA POPOVICI
▻ Entrepreneurship in the age of data science

Elena is a Computer Science PhD with over a dozen years of industry experience managing science-driven projects using algorithms to solve complex, real-world business and engineering problems across a wide variety of domains. Elena is currently a Project Lead at Neurio, where she uses machine learning to forecast electricity consumption and generation from solar panels, and optimization to intelligently operate a battery based on these forecasts in order to reduce the grid demand during peak periods. Elena also volunteers with the BC Sustainable Energy Association and co-organizes the Data Science for Social Good meetup.

title: Vancouver Data Visualization: IEEE VIS meets Vancouver
description:
IEEE VIS (http://ieeevis.org), one of the highest rated conferences for visualization research and computer graphics, is in Vancouver this year!

We think this is a great opportunity for the international visitors to see what’s happening in Vancouver's Data Viz community, and for the locals (who might not be able to attend the conference) to get a glimpse of the latest research in that area.

☞ TELL US ABOUT YOUR WORK!
Anybody who is willing to share their visualization work (research, projects, ideas) we'd love to see a 2-5 minute presentation from you!
Feel free to contact me, then we can talk about the details and I'll put you on the agenda - or just come by and we'll play it by ear.

We'll kick it off with those presentations and then should have enough time afterwards to network, ask follow-up questions, mingle and eat pizza.

BrainStation (https://brainstation.io) will host us this time - many thanks!!

It's a great venue - and super conveniently close to the Convention Center, where the conference is at (5 minute walk)

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Advanced Regression Models with R Applications
description:
**SIGN UP ON EVENTBRITE **
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-advanced-regression-models-with-r-applications-tickets-70416075377

In this workshop, we will talk about a variety of regression models, give their definitions, discussing goodness-of-fit criteria, presenting fitted models, interpreting estimated regression coefficients, and using the fitted models for prediction. The models will be limited to: linear regression, Box-Cox transformation, gamma regression, ordinary logistic regression, Poisson regression, beta regression, longitudinal (repeated measures) regression, and hierarchical model.

The workshop is designed to be hands-on. Participants are required to bring laptops and be ready to write R, analyzing data and interpreting results. For each model, we present an example with a complete R code, and then will an exercise to work on. Workshop participants should be familiar with algebraic expressions of different probability distributions and have a fundamental knowledge of simple linear regression: normally distributed random error, continuous and categorical independent variables (requiring creating dummy variables).

The material covered by the workshop will be taken from my recently published book “Advanced Regression Models with SAS and R Applications”, CRC Press, 2018.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Using YAML and Python in your R Workflow
description:
# Introduction

Malcolm has been interning with RStudio and working on a package, ymlthis, which will allow you too write YAML code using R. The goal is to make it easier to create the metadata needed by markdown, bookdown, blogdown and other frameworks used in R.

R and Python are both popular languages in Data Science. There is no need to limit yourself to just one. Michael will show us how to incorporate python into your R workflow.

Come early, network, enjoy the food and talks.

# Schedule
6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 7:30 The YAML problem: Writing and working with YAML with ymlthis
7:30 - 8:00 Snakes in the Studio: Adding Python to your R Workflow
8:00 - Raffle
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

# Talk 1

## Title: The YAML problem: Writing and working with YAML with ymlthis
## Speaker: Malcolm Barrett
## Abstract
R Markdown is an easy-to-learn tool for reproducible research. Many people, however, bump into problems using YAML, the language that specifies metadata for R Markdown documents. ymlthis makes it easy to write valid YAML by handling the syntax and documenting the majority of YAML fields in one place. ymlthis will help you write metadata for R Markdown, bookdown, blogdown, and more. Let the Shiny add-in create a new R Markdown file for you or work with YAML and R Markdown files directly. ymlthis finally gives you a workflow that is better than trying to find and paste the YAML from the last R Markdown document you used.

# Talk 2

## Title: Snakes in the Studio: Adding Python to your R Workflow
## Speaker: Michael Espero
## Abstract
R and Python are among the most widely used programming languages for analysts and data scientists. While it’s great to feel comfortable in one open-source statistical programming language, you may encounter peers who prefer another. This walk-through aims to share some of RStudio’s versatility as we touch on useful commonalities between data science workflows in R and Python with attention to simple approaches to loading, wrangling, visualizing, and modelling publicly available data.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Data Science Hackathon - **Signup on Eventbrite not Meetup**
description:
We are excited to announce that the second Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) data science hackathon now has tickets available. It is a weekend-long event on Nov 09 and 10th.

**********************
You can purchase tickets on eventbrite.
https://tinyurl.com/hackathon-2019-11
**********************

This is the first Orange Country R Users Group (OCRUG) data science hackathon. During this event, we will be exploring an interesting data set, starting from the raw data all the way through to a final "end product" (e.g. a data visualization, an interesting data insight, a predictive model, etc.).

This event is open to all experience levels, from the complete beginner to the highly experienced. Participants will work in teams to "hack" through the data and will present their work at the end of the event for prizes. You are free to create your own team, or we will assist in team creation if you do not have one. This is a great way to network, share, and learn from others.

The main goal of the hackathon is to promote team work and foster education and learning in a welcoming environment. Though teams will competing to present their best work at the end of the event for prizes, communication and providing assistance across teams is highly encouraged. We will provide in-person training during the hackathon and online training prior to the event.

Participants will need to bring their own computers during the event.

We have set up a GitHub repository that has more information about the hackathon. Such as the schedule; setting up slack and much more. Further information will be provided prior to the event.

Your ticket includes meals, snacks and drinks during the event. Optionally, parking at UCI is $10 per day.

All participants must abide by the OCRUG Code of Conduct and R Consortium Code of Conduct.

Your ticket includes meals, snacks and drinks during the event. Optionally, parking at UCI is $10 per day.

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: St. Petersburg R User Group: SPbR #15
description:
Василий Каминский, тех. аналитик, JetBrains
Анализ временных рядов

На работе я регулярно сталкиваюсь с задачами анализа и прогнозирования временных рядов. В своём рассказе я затрону базовые понятия, принципы и модели временных рядов (AR, MA и их более сложные модификации) с примерами на языке R. Доклад будет полезен начинающим аналитикам, аналитикам данных, специалистам по машинному обучению и всем заинтересованным.

Владимир Завьялов, специалист по измерительным машинам
Использование R в машиностроении

Рассказ о том как R упростил анализ результатов измерения на производстве электромеханических приводов.

Владимир Кошелев, разработчик R Plugin, JetBrains
R Plugin

Компания JetBrains последнее время разрабатывает плагин к PyCharm для языка R. В своем докладе я покажу и расскажу, что у нас получилось.

*****
Самая актуальная информация, материалы и записи докладов в группе https://vk.com/spbrug

Обратите внимание: в этот раз мы встречаемся в новом офисе JetBrains у метро Беговая.

title: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group: October R meetup - two talks about R + network with other R enthusiasts!
group: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group
description:
Join us for the October meetup of the Toronto R group! We will have two featured talks:

*Michael Enquist* will be talking about Association Rules in R and how to apply them to grocery shopping. Association rules are statements that help to find patterns in seemingly unrelated data or a relational database (information repository). When we apply to a user purchasing a product, we will try to show five other products that the user is most likely to buy together with this product.

*Madeleine Bonsma-Fisher* (and possibly some of her collaborators) will be talking about a graduate student-led participatory live-coding quantitative methods course in R.

Doors will open at 6:00pm, with talks kicking off at 6:30. After the talks you're welcome to stick around for some networking, and by 8:00 we'll leave the room (but may head somewhere nearby to continue the conversation!).

The event will be held at Insight Data Science, so please remember to thank them.

By attending, you agree to abide by our code of conduct which can be found at https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Plus de détails à venir...

Passionné par l'informatique et le machine learning et après une première vie dans la recherche, Nicolas Greffard est aujourd'hui data scientist et responsable de l'innovation chez Valeuriad où il intervient sur des missions de conseil et d'expertise autour de la data science.

title: Meetup R Nantes: "Rmd first" : Quand le développement commence par la documentation...
description:
Titre complet : "Rmd first" : Quand le développement commence par la documentation (ou "N'ayez pas peur de faire un package...")

Les analyses, les programmes R ou les packages sont plus faciles à utiliser et à maintenir lorsqu'ils sont correctement documentés. Cependant, la documentation semble prendre beaucoup de temps et, lorsqu'elle est incluse, elle est habituellement la dernière chose ajoutée à un projet. Pour un projet reproductible, les workflows peuvent être présentés dans un fichier Rmarkdown, combinant explications et analyses. Nous allons nous appuyer sur ce format Rmd pour s'assurer de la pérennité de nos travaux.
Nous tenterons au passage de désacraliser la création de package. En continuant d'écrire notre code (presque) comme d'habitude mais en faisant les bons copier-coller au bon moment, on peut développer des analyses avec toute la documentation nécessaire sans (trop d')efforts. Le format package simplifie le partage, les tests, la maintenance et la présentation de son travail.

Sébastien Rochette est formateur-consultant en R chez ThinkR. Avant de rejoindre le privé, il est passé par un doctorat en écologie halieutique à Agrocampus Ouest (Rennes), puis un poste de chercheur en cartographie des habitats marins à Ifremer Brest.
Son site web : https://statnmap.com
Son twitter : https://twitter.com/statnmap

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): October useR Group: Shiny in Production!
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Shiny in Production!
Presented by Sean Lopp, RStudio

Abstract:
Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R, a language not traditionally known for web frameworks, to say the least. As such, Shiny has always faced questions about whether it can or should be used “in production”. In this talk, we’ll explore what “production” even means, review some of the historical obstacles and objections to using Shiny for production purposes, and discuss practices and tools that can help your Shiny apps flourish.

Bio:
Sean Lopp is a Product Manager at RStudio. Sean leads teams to create useful, enjoyable products. Before RStudio he was a data scientist and worked on alternative vehicle models at NREL, infant sleep dynamics, and originally studied mathematics. He lives outside Denver, CO and skis and bikes with his family.

We welcome all newcomers, enthusiasts, and experts.

* Pizza will be provided by RStudio
* Event location provided by WeWork

WeWork is a global network of workspaces where companies grow together. Teams of any size can find refreshingly designed collaborative space, private offices, and meeting rooms that energize their employees and their guests. But WeWork is so much more than four walls—providing community, amenities, events, and technology to evolve space into experience.

title: DuPage R Meetup: Data Mining with Amazon Web Services by Andy Roy
description:
Data Mining with Amazon Web Services by Andy Roy. Use the power of cloud-based services to enhance and visualize relationships in your business or personal data. Most business analysts are constrained by Excel to simplistic data visualization. We will review several techniques in R to automate tasks and produce colorful, engaging insights from the data you already have in Excel or business databases. This talk will be approachable for beginners and interesting for advanced R users as well. The code demonstrated will be shared via GitHub, and the packages we will review included aws, comprehend (NLP), pdftools & officer (text scraping), dplyr & ggplot, visNetwork (directed graphs), mongolite (MongoDB in the cloud), and Shiny.

Andy will start his presentation at about 6:00. We'll have meet-n-greet both before and after. You do not need to show up exactly at 5:30 nor stay until 8. Thanks to Innovation DuPage and Benedictine University for the free pizza and pop and free meeting space.

About the Speaker: Andy Roy is a digital marketing consultant with 30+ years industry experience in companies such as Neustar, Wipro Digital, Experian, Razorfish and Microsoft. His interest in R comes from developing business reporting applications.

About Innovation DuPage: https://innovationdupage.org/

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Data R for Kids
description:
Exciting talk and co-creation event by Sine Zambach:

Data R for Kids
==============

We know from tobacco industry, that we should get’em while they are young. But if we should get young people using in R – what would it require? To a start [someone] should develop a new set of exercises that can engage kids and young people to explore data science and (R)-programming. Not sports results or airplane time tables. Exercises should be simple and funny and relate to the everyday of the young students.
This event is a co-creation, and I will only entertain briefly. After this, we are all in center in designing and perhaps taking the first steps in having a library of R-exercises for kids.

title: Zurich R User Group: Quantitative Analysis of Textual Data & UseR 2019
description:
Schedule:
6.15 pm Doors open
6.30 pm Welcome Zurich RUG
6.40 pm Talks (see below)
7.45 pm Are you hiring? Looking for an R related job? ... or organising an interesting event? Take the stage for one minute. (DM us if you need a slot!)
~ 8 - 9 pm Beer & Apéro sponsored by cynkra & R consortium

***

### \pkg{quanteda}: Quantitative Analysis of Textual Data
# Stefan Müller, Postdoc @Department of Political Science, UZH
In recent times the availability of textual data has increased massively, and there are multiple opportunities to analyse texts in the private sector or to answer social science research questions. Stefan Müller introduces quanteda, an R package for natural language processing tasks such as corpus management, tokenization, analysis, and visualisation (https://quanteda.io). By emphasizing consistent design, the package lowers the barriers to learning quantitative text analysis. In addition to introducing quanteda and the typical workflow, Stefan will outline challenges and future directions of text-as-data methods.

***

### useR!2019 Toulouse : ZRH-PARIS-BORDEAUX-TOULOUSE
# Matt Bannert, KOF Konjunkturforschungsstelle, ETH Zürich
The 2019 edition of the biggest R show on the planet is in the books.
About three months later, R enthusiasts from around the world returned from their trip to southern France, the community has somewhat digested the gathering. Discussions with other attendees, the posters, videos of the talks and reflection of the very own live experience have helped to disentangle highlights and process impressions.
If you could not attend, this talk is a chance to catch a glimpse of the useR! experience. And even if you have been to Toulouse in July -- you might hear about a talk or two you could not attend.
In any case: Be prepared to travel to Milano (eRum) or St. Louis (useR!) in 2020 as the talk will increase your fear of missing out!

***

title: Inland Northwest R User Group (INRUG): Google Deep Dream: What does my network actually see?
description:
Abstract: In this talk we will look at Neural Networks for object recognition in images (vgg16 and possibly inception). We will talk about how the network learns and how learning affects what the network is seeing, that is, What are the features that the network uses to "understand" that an object is present? This will further lead us to a discussion of gradient-based learning and how it affects the ability of the network to do what we train it to do. If we have time we will show how this leads to the possibility of "fooling" the algorithm into thinking it sees something that isn't present.

Speaker: Joe Dumoulin, Chief Technology Innovation Officer at Verint Intelligent Self Service

When and Where: October 5, 9.30 AM, Jepson 122 (School of Business Administration, Gonzaga University)

title: Sevilla R Users: Reunión SevillaR: 1 Octubre. Procesamiento de Lenguaje Natural con R
description:
¡Empezamos nuevo curso en SevillaR!

El próximo martes 1 de Octubre Montse López Cobo (https://www.linkedin.com/in/montserrat-l%C3%B3pez-cobo-25069ab1/), Scientific Project Officer en el Joint Research Centre de la Unión Europea, nos hablará sobre Procesamiento del Lenguaje Natural con R.

El procesamiento del lenguaje natural (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing) es un campo en intenso desarrollo y con múltiples aplicaciones, como la minería y análisis de textos, interpretación y generación del lenguaje, chatbots, etc.

El encuentro será en el aula TIC4 (2ª planta) del edificio CRAI (https://bib.us.es/ulloa) del campus de Reina Mercedes, a las 19 horas.

Tras la conferencia tendremos la oportunidad de hablar sobre nuestros proyectos en R y conocernos mejor tomando unas cervezas en el Aljibe, muy cercano al CRAI.

¡Os esperamos!

title: Greater Cleveland R Group: Teaching Lab R&D Chemists using RMD and Shiny with Mukul Mehta
description:
Lab R&D Chemists in Chemical, Food, Plastic, Polymer and Pharma industries are very creative and constantly develop new products over time. Their R&D Managers worry, that R&D is very slow and struggle to speed up NPD. Many big companies like DuPont, Dow, BF Goodrich Chemical and others have tried to bring new statistical and mathematical methods in-house, but without much success.

Mukul Mehta will examine several problems he has identified and an R/Shiny based solution that he is developing to address these problems. Mukul hopes to train 10,000 Lab R&D chemists over three years.

title: IndyUseR Group: Reproducible workflows at scale with drake
description: Ambitious workflows in R, such as machine learning analyses, can be difficult to manage. A single round of computation can take several hours to complete, and routine updates to the code and data tend to invalidate hard-earned results. You can enhance the maintainability, hygiene, speed, scale, and reproducibility of such projects with the drake R package. drake resolves the dependency structure of your analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and organizes the output so you rarely have to think about data files. This talk demonstrates how to create and maintain a realistic machine learning project using drake-powered automation.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Using R for geospatial applications at the USDA
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our next Meetup will be downtown at Neumont College. City Creek has free two hour parking or you can take the Trax blue or green line to the Gallivan Plaza or City Center stations. Phil Roberts from the USDA will present.

Summary: The US Department of Agriculture is using R / RStudio to solve a variety of geospatial data questions.  We will discuss various geospatial data models and how they are handled in R, as well as some of the relevant packages for dealing with geographic data.  We will look at how the National Cooperative Soil Survey and the Aerial Photography Field Office are improving current methods, with more explicit and quantitative approaches to current workflows.  USDA Staff have developed innovative packages (AQP, SharpshootR, SoilDB, cLHS) to help with the visualization and analysis of soil profile data.  We discuss an example of how USDA is applying machine learning to aerial imagery to learn changes in the agricultural landscape.

Bio: I’ve been using R and R Studio for ~12 years, and it represented my first introduction to coding.  I graduated from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo with a BS Earth Science and a BS in Soil Science and went on to earn a MS in Soil Science from Washington State University.  I started my career with the USDA in 2009 as a soil scientist in Mt Vernon, Washington mapping Soils and Ecological Sites at North Cascades, Mount Rainier and Olympic National Parks.  Last year I accepted a position as a cartographer here in Salt Lake City where my current project involves applying machine learning to aerial imagery to map land cover and relating these maps to farm records databases.  I use R to solve geospatial problems such as, sample design, data clustering, data visualizations, predictive modeling and quality control. 

The meeting will be live streamed on YouTube on the Utah R Users Group channel.

title: Oslo useR! Group: OsloUseR::inner_join(). OUR community meeting
description:
Dear R-enthusiasts,

You might have noticed that we announced community meeting on 15 October 2019. The purpose of this event is to look back at the events we enjoyed last year, celebrate growth and diversity of our community and discuss the road ahead. We will have a few lightning talks (10-15 min) on diverse subjects and leave time for discussions and reflections on how UseR meetups helped you grow or learn in the last year.

In order to ensure constant flow of fun and useful events, we need to have people organizing them and making sure speakers, venues and practicalities are taken care of in time for every new UseR meeting. We would like to elect Organizing Committee consisting of 5-6 members, who would take on responsibility to serve the community in the next 12 months. Here are some of the topics that Organizing Committee will assume responsibility for:
1) Recruiting speakers for the events
2) Arranging venues
3) Applying for and arranging sponsor support for the group
4) Keeping community informed through timely announcements and event marketing
5) Maintaining relationship with partner organizations, such as R-Ladies, global UseR network, and other meetups in Oslo.

Based on the experience from last year, these duties should not take more than 3-4 hours per month, but we want to avoid the situation where everyone assumes somebody else is taking care of a particular issue and in the end no one steps up to the responsibility.

Acting as a Meetup Organizer goes beyond the line on the resume. It means meeting new people, expanding your network and talking to colleagues in senior positions in data community. You also make yourself known to the wider community of R users around the world, get inspired to pursue cool projects and interesting ideas and generally grow as an R programmer and a data professional.

We are hereby inviting you to nominate yourself to a community service position at the Oslo UseR Organizing Committee! If you have been enjoying our meetups, now you have the chance to make sure others can enjoy them, too!

Please, post your name and a couple of sentences describing your motivation for serving at the Oslo UseR Organizing Committee for the year 2019/2020 here:
https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/messages/boards/thread/52386458/0/

Thank you very much for your dedication to spreading knowledge of R and your support for Oslo UseR community!

On behalf of interim Organizer Committee,

Dmytro

title: Malaysia R User Public Group: confeRence 2019
description:
* This is a PAID event. Get your ticket here https://www.ticket2u.com.my/event/15007

Join us for this year's confeRence 2019 event on 5th October 2019, where we'll bring together R enthusiasts and the developer, data scientist and machine learning community to be a part of the R community experience.

title: Saint Louis R User Group: Machine Learning in R with mlr3
description:
By: Matt Dube

mlr3 (https://mlr3.mlr-org.com/) is the next generation of the mlr R package. It provides a generic, object-oriented, and extensible framework for classification, regression, survival analysis, and other machine learning tasks for the R language.

This discussion will take a brief look at the past and present of machine learning in R, and then take a detailed look at how mlr3 attempts to refine and improve the current processes and tools. This will include a sample project code walkthrough, and references for further study.

The meetup will be in The Showroom in the CIC building at 20 South Sarah Street, St. Louis, MO 63108. The building entrance is at the corner of Forest Park Avenue and Sarah Street. You can find directions at http://stl.cic.us/directions/ (CIC@CET).

We will meet for snacks, set-up, and conversation at 6:00PM. The presentation will start at 6:30PM and will be about 60 minutes long.

title: Portland R User Group: ruODK? Electronic Data Capture with R and ODK: From form design to insight in 0$
description:
Electronic Data Capture (EDC) as a replacement for traditional paper-based data capture can streamline the path from observation to analysis by cutting out redundant, resource-intensive, and error-prone steps of data transcription. OpenDataKit (ODK, https://opendatakit.org/) is a Free and Open Source (FOSS) software suite for EDC. ODK has a world-wide user community (https://forum.opendatakit.org/), an active developer community, a sustainable business model, comes at no cost to users, and is targeted towards resource-restricted, remote and offline data capture. ODK users include Google, WHO, CDC, USAID, the Red Cross and Red Crescent, the Carter Center, the Jane Goodall Institute and many others.
​
In this session, we will run through the process of EDC end to end, with the option of participating in each step.
We will design a new EDC form using the online form builder ODK Build (https://build.opendatakit.org/), then publish the form on DBCA's ODK Central instance (https://odkcentral.dbca.wa.gov.au/, credentials given out on the day), download the forms, capture and submit some data using ODK Collect, and lastly use ruODK to access, wrangle, and analyse the data using ruODK.
​
Interested participants can obtain a login to the ODK Central Sandbox (https://sandbox.central.opendatakit.org/), so they can continue to evaluate ODK (with our without ruODK) in a no-cost environment.

Details
​
Activity: Live demo and code-along for those who are keen

Duration: ca 45 mins; some prep for audience hands-on beforehand

Target audience: Practicing R users with an interest in electronic data capture using FOSS.

If interested in hands-on, bring:
* To build your own form: Sign up for a free account at https://build.opendatakit.org/
* To collect your own data: Bring an Android device with ODK Collect installed.
* To access and analyse the data: Bring a Laptop with R and ruODK with dependencies intstalled (https://dbca-wa.github.io/ruODK/)
Come 30 mins early to do your ruODK/ODK Collect installation on the day.
​​
​​About the presenter
​
Florian Mayer is an Ecoinformatician at the Western Australian Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) working on threatened species and ecological communities with a focus on marine turtles (North West Shelf Flatback Turtle Conservation Program, https://flatbacks.dbca.wa.gov.au/). Florian has introduced ODK to DBCA's and affiliated Western Australian turtle monitoring programs in 2016 (~30k records captured through ~500 staff and volunteers since 2016) and authored ruODK.
​
